ABERDEEN PROVING GROUND, Md. — The Army's General Dynamics (GD)-made Stryker troop carrier could get a high-powered laser in the future to shoot down bomb-laden drones, as ISIS employs these so-called flying IEDs.To combat the growing unmanned air system (UAS) threat, the Army tested Boeing's (BA) Mobile High Energy Laser, a 5-kilowatt laser cannon, mounted on a Stryker, at Fort Sill, Okla., back in April."I'm very optimistic about lasers for counter-UAS missions," Maj. Gen. David Bassett, the Army's acquisition executive for ground combat systems, told a group of reporters at a media day Tuesday.But before the Army can use lasers to zap enemy tanks and other vehicles, "there are hard physics problems " that need to be solved first, he added.For example, a laser beam spreads out as it travels, making it less powerful the farther away the target is from the laser's source.So for a laser to be effective against a large target, like a tank, it either needs to be more powerful than 5 kilowatts or remain on the target for perhaps hours, rendering the laser impractical in combat.IBD'S TAKE: Defense stocks have been on the rise as tensions heat up across the globe, and General Dynamics stock is in buy range. You can find other top stocks near buy range and deeper chart analysis in IBD's review screens. Right now, the Army is just starting to demonstrate laser capabilities, and Col. Glenn Dean, the Stryker's project manager, said he isn't sure if lasers would be included in an official Stryker program anytime soon.General Dynamics shares edged up 0.4% on the stock market today. Boeing shares slipped 0.7%.RELATED:Watch The Army's Stryker Fire Its New Anti-Russia WeaponsDefense And Aerospace Stocks To Watch And Industry News

ABERDEEN PROVING GROUND, Md. — The Army showed off its latest iteration of General Dynamics' (GD) Stryker vehicle Tuesday, now packed with more firepower than ever as tensions heat up with Russia.XThere are only 30,000 U.S. troops in Europe, down from the 300,000 at the height of the Cold War, and the U.S. doesn't have a lot of armor in Europe anymore, Lt. Col. Troy Meissel, deputy commanding officer of the 2nd Cavalry Regiment, based in Germany, told IBD.The Strykers that his unit operates are armored troop carriers that aren't designed to slug it out with tanks. Meanwhile, Russia's invasions into Georgia in 2008 and Ukraine in 2014 have raised fears in Europe of more Russian aggression.So the more heavily armed Strykers now feature a 30-mm cannon, an upgrade from the 0.50-caliber machine gun. The cannon, which is remotely operated with an unmanned turret, can provide more stand-off range and shoots armor-piercing as well as high-explosive/incendiary rounds. A machine gun can also be mounted on the turret along with a Javelin anti-tank missile launcher.Meissel said the new weapons can hold off and slow down a surprise attack from Russian tanks, troop carriers and other lightly armored vehicles until U.S. tanks and other reinforcements can arrive."We don't fight tanks or armored vehicles," he said. "The goal is to survive those chance contacts."General Dynamics shares rose 0.6% at 200.61 on the stock market today, retaking their 50-day average. They remain in buy range after breaking out in April, but the stock hasn't moved much over those months.IBD'S TAKE: Defense stocks have been on the rise as tensions heat up across the globe, and General Dynamics stock is in buy range. You can find other top stocks near buy range and deeper chart analysis in IBD's review screens. Delivery of the vehicle — nicknamed Dragoon after the 2nd Cavalry Regiment, which requested the vehicles — starts in January, with all 81 vehicles expected to be delivered by July 2018.As deployment nears, there are still issues that need to be worked out. For example, soldiers are concerned about reduced visibility due to the removal of hatches for the 30-mm cannon's turret.But Major Gen. David G. Bassett, the Army's program executive officer for ground combat systems, said the service is working through possible solutions.RELATED: Here's What The Army Can And Can't Destroy With This LaserWatch The Aircraft In The Air Force's Light-Attack ExperimentDefense And Aerospace Stocks To Watch And Industry News

The major market indexes were quietly higher in early trade Monday. The tech-heavy Nasdaq perked up with a 0.3% gain, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average both rose less than 0.1% each.XAmong the Dow industrials, Boeing (BA) and McDonald's (MCD) advanced 0.5% and 0.9%, respectively. The airplane maker remains just off its highs and has been solid advancer since its flat-base breakout on May 8. Shares have risen about 30% from the 160.17 entry.Meanwhile, the restaurant chain is rebounding from its 50-day line. This is the second test of the key support level since its late-March cup-with-handle breakout. The stock is up almost 20% from the 130.10 buy point.Apple (AAPL) was moving back above its flat-base entry in the stock market today. The iPhone maker gained 0.7% and reclaimed its 156.75 buy point.On the downside, United Technologies (UTX) dropped over 2% after reports indicated the company is considering a purchase of aerospace company Rockwell Collins (COL). Rockwell jumped over 4%.Chip stocks were some of the day's top performers. Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) and Nvidia (NVDA) advanced 2.3% and 1.1%, respectively. Leading graphics chip maker Nvidia was trading just shy of a fresh all-time high.Among leading stocks, Tesla (TSLA) traded 0.3% higher after the company announced it was raising more cash to fund its Model 3 rollout. The electric automaker is building a cup-shaped base with a 387.09 buy point after reclaiming its 50-day line last week.Meanwhile, IBD Sector Leader Essent Group (ESNT) attemped to follow up Friday's breakout with another solid advance, but an over 2% gain reversed to a 0.1% decline. Shares remain in buy range from a 39.60 flat-base entry.Among analyst actions, Grubhub (GRUB) was upgraded to overweight at Morgan Stanley based on the company's recent deal to purchase Eat24 from Yelp (YELP). Grubhub moved up over 3% early Monday and is extended from a 47.94 flat-base buy point.Within the IBD 50, China-based YY (YY) and Sina (SINA) jumped 5% and 3%, respectively. YY was trading over 25% from a 61.62 flat-base entry, while Sina was breaking out of a cup-base with a 97.90 buy point.On the downside, Stamps.com (STMP) declined over 2% as it gave back a slight portion of last week's heady gains. The electronic postage provider surged almost 36% Thursday after an earnings beat. Shares are over 50% above a 136.10 cup-base buy point.RELATED:2 Top Chinese Stocks Break Out Ahead Of EarningsGrubhub Gets Post-Yelp Upgrade; Charter, NXP Targets Hiked Amid Merger BuzzHotel Giant Closes In On Buy Point On Deal With AlibabaNvidia, Disney, China Stocks Lead 'Monster' Week: Investing Action PlanChip Stocks To Watch And Semiconductor Industry NewsDow Jones industrial average And Dow Stocks: News And Analysis

Apple (AAPL) earnings helped lift the Dow Jones industrial average above 22,000 but didn't help the Nasdaq composite or S&P 500 index. Tesla (TSLA) topped forecasts while General Motors (GM) and other U.S. automakers reported weak domestic sales. Applied Optoelectronics (AAOI) crashed as it and other fiber-optic plays had weak guidance or results. The U.S. economy continued to grow and hire at a moderate pace.The major market averages continued to split. The Dow Jones industrial average continued to rack up small gains, climbing 1.2% and topping 22,000 for the first time. The S&P 500 edged up 0.2% while the Nasdaq composite fell 0.4%. Apple, Tesla had well-received June quarter results, while many stocks had big double-digit percentage gains or losses. Optical stocks were losers on Applied Optoelectronics and others.Consumer electronics giant Apple beat Wall Street's sales and earnings targets in the June quarter and guided higher for the September quarter, easing concerns about a late iPhone 8 launch. Earnings rose 18% while sales climbed 7% to $45.4 billion. Cirrus Logic (CRUS) and Qorvo (QRVO) also topped estimates, implying healthy business from Apple. Apple advanced 4.6%, but closed below a buy point after clearing it on Wednesday. Apple chipmakers struggled.RELATED:This Is Why Apple Is Bullish On Q4 Sales (It's Not The iPhone 8)Tesla (TSLA) reported a smaller-than-expected adjusted loss, while second-quarter revenue more than doubled from the year-ago quarter to reaching $2.79 billion. Tesla received several price-target hikes following its quarterly earnings report that beat views, though analysts expressed concern about the electric car company's ability to execute on its ambitious production schedule for the new Model 3. Analysts also are concerned about Tesla's cash burn. But the stock rose 6.55%, clearing its 50-day moving average.Here's What Analysts Like And Don't Like About Tesla EarningsBefore Ordering A Tesla Model 3 Or Chevy Bolt, Look At This ChartApplied Optoelectronics sees weak revenue for the current quarter, shocker given that the optical stock had raised or beaten guidance several times this year. It cited some slower demand from a large customer, which could be Amazon. Applied Opto, the No. 1 stock in the No. 1-rated Telecom-Fiber Optics group, crashed 34% Friday. Acacia Communications (ACIA) and Infinera (INFN) also had bad news late Thursday. Earlier in the week, Macom Technology Solutions Holdings (MTSI), an optical-related chipmaker, sees weak China demand. However, Oclaro (OCLR) reported better-than-expected fiscal fourth-quarter profit and revenue and sees strong demand in the current fiscal year. But Oclaro shares still plunged for the week.RELATED:Applied Optoelectronics Plunges On Weak Guidance; Opticals HitJuly was a rout for U.S. auto sales, marking the biggest monthly decline since August 2010. General Motors (GM) saw sales plunge 15% vs. the expected 9% to 11%. Ford Motor (F) sales declined nearly 8% vs. an expected 5% to 6%. Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) sales declined 11% vs. an expected 7%. Industrywide U.S. auto sales rang in at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 16.77 million in July, Autodata reported, marking the third straight month below 17 million. The auto giants pointed to planned fleet sales cutbacks, but their retail sales also retreated. Toyota (TM) saw U.S. sales unexpectedly rise, while Japanese peers Nissan (NSANY) and Honda (HMC) had smaller-than-expected declines.RELATED:U.S. Auto Sales Tumble 7%, Worst Drop In Nearly 7 YearsThe U.S. economy added 209,000 jobs in July, slightly more than expected. The unemployment rate ticked down to 4.3% while average hourly wages rose a solid 0.3%. The report is more evidence of tighter labor markets, though it likely won't shift the Federal Reserve's policy path in the near future. Meanwhile, ISM surveys signaled still-strong manufacturing growth while some decelerating growth in the service sector.Grubhub (GRUB) and Yelp (Yelp) both topped second-quarter earnings and revenue estimates late Thursday. As part of a long-term partnership, Grubhub will pay $287.5 million in cash to acquire Yelp's online food ordering and delivery business, Eat24. The partnership comes as Amazon (AMZN) is getting more aggressive in the food delivery market. Grubhub rose 9.2% on Friday while Yelp shot up nearly 28%.Symantec (SYMC), Qualys (QYLS) and FireEye (FEYE) reported better-than-expected June-quarter results, following computer security peer Proofpoint (PFPT) last week. Symantec's adjusted fiscal first-quarter earnings rose 14% as revenue climbed 39% to $1.23 billion. Symantec agreed to sell its website security business to DigiCert for about $950 million cash. But Symantec shares fell 6%. Qualys EPS climbed 30% as revenue rose 14% to $55.3 million, sending shares 13.8% for the week. FireEye narrowed its Q2 loss to just 4 cents a share as revenue grew 6% to $185.5 million, amid strong demand for its new Helix security platform. Shares fell 6%.Video game publishers Activision Blizzard (ATVI) and Take-Two Interactive Software (TTWO) reported better-than-expected June-quarter results, while mobile and online games publisher Zynga (ZNGA) delivered a mixed report. Activision climbed 4% through Thursday to fresh highs, but retreated 3.1% Friday on its mixed guidance. Take-Two spiked 9.5%, breaking out past a buy point to its own high. Zynga was little changed, in a consolidation at 3-year highs.RELATED:Activision Blizzard Beats Second-Quarter Views, Offers Mixed OutlookVideo Game Publisher Take-Two Rockets On June-Quarter BeatBoeing (BA) announced that it would get into the avionics business, to make controls and electronics for aircraft and spacecraft. The aerospace giant said the unit would first supply parts for its own aircraft but eventually sell to other firms. Analysts worried that would hurt suppliers like Rockwell Collins (COL) and Honeywell (HON). Boeing also announced a pricing deal with Spirit AeroSystems (SPR) on supplies for its 787 Dreamliner. Spirit has a similar deal with Airbus (EADSY) for its A350. Spirit Aero, which also announced strong earnings, soared 17.2%.The ObamaCare exchanges are still perilous for insurers' earnings health, but Medicare is a cash cow. Aetna (AET) and Humana (HUM), which will both complete their exit from the individual insurance markets at year end, both sailed past earnings estimates thanks to momentum in their Medicare Advantage businesses, and their shares vaulted to record highs. Aetna earnings ballooned by 55% and Humana earnings grew 6%, both smashing views. Cigna (CI) and WellCare Health Plans (WCG) also reported strong earnings. But Molina Healthcare (MOH), which saw the exchanges as a big growth opportunity, reported a loss of $4.10 a share in Q2, largely blaming its ObamaCare exchange business. Molina will pull out of the Wisconsin and Utah markets and scale back its presence in Washington state. In its remaining markets, Molina said it will hike premiums at least 30% in 2018. Molina shares tumbled.RELATED:Aetna Trounces Expectations As Big ObamaCare Insurer CrashesVulcan Materials (VMC) and Martin Marietta Materials (MLM), huge suppliers of construction aggregates, both reported earnings below views. Both companies cited wet weather across the Southeast for delaying shipments. Vulcan said some coastal Texas energy and highway projects were pushed back, while Illinois business has been hit by the state's budget crisis. As proxies for infrastructure spending, the stocks soared after President Trump's surprise election. While there hasn't been any movement on infrastructure at the federal level, both companies are upbeat about growing backlogs and stronger pricing, and Wall Street analysts seem convinced that they'll gain traction later this year.RELATED:Trump Touts Market Prowess As Trump Stocks Erase Post-Election GainsEOG Resources (EOG), Oasis Petroleum (OAS), and Devon Energy (DVN) reported mixed quarterly results, while Diamondback Energy (FANG), Rice Energy (RICE) and Pioneer Natural Resources (PXD) beat and Concho Resources (CXO), Parsley Energy (PE) missed. EOG and Parsley kept their capex guidance steady while Pioneer, Diamondback and Rice cut their outlook. U.S. crude inventories fell less than expected last week, according to the Energy Information Administration, with production levels rebounding from the prior week. Crude prices flirted with $50 after a recent run-up but pulled back to about $49.Burger King and Tim Hortons parent Restaurant Brands International (QSR) reported mixed Q2 results. Burger King helped, but weaker sales from Tim Hortons did not. Papa John's (PZZA) Q2 was also mixed, hurt by international comp sales amid slowness in the U.K.. But the pizza chain hiked its leverage ratio and buyback plan, cheering investors. Taco Bell, KFC and Pizza Hut parent Yum Brands (YUM) beat. Wingstop (WING) initiated a dividend after Q2 earnings topped.SunPower (SPWR) reported second-quarter earnings that beat estimates, but the stock plunged 18.5% as the solar power company sees current-quarter revenue falling far below estimates.Square (SQ) Q2 earnings beat and the digital payment processor bumped up full-year guidance. Shares fell 3.8 for the week as analysts questioned Square's valuation after a big run-up, but they closed above a recent buy point and the 50-day line.Paycom Software (PAYC) stock slipped 1.4% after the provider of human resources and payroll processing software reported Q2 earnings and profit that topped views but issued current quarter guidance that was in-line.Match Group (MTCH) named a new CEO as of Jan. 1 and reported Q2 earnings and profit that missed expectations but shares in the online dating service edged up 1.45%.Coherent (COHR) plunged 20.6% Wednesday after quarterly earnings fell short. The maker of laser technologies reported EPS of $3.36 on revenue of $464.1 million. Analysts were expecting adjusted earnings of $3.45 and revenue of 466.9 million.Under Armour (UAA) swung to a per-share loss of 3 cents on 9% revenue growth to $1.09 billion. Sales in its key North America market fell 1% on "business lost to bankruptcies in 2017." The athletic apparel brand trimmed full-year revenue guidance and said it would lay off 280 employees, about 2% of its workforce, as part of a restructuring effort intended to boost go-to-market speed and digital capabilities. Under Armour slid 5.4% through Thursday, hitting four-year lows.Nike (NKE), meanwhile, moved into buy range. U.S. shares of Adidas (ADDYY) traded near record highs as the European athletic apparel giant makes big gains in North America.

American Airlines (AAL) and Spirit Airlines (SAVE) were upgraded Tuesday, while Regeneron (REGN) was downgraded and Rockwell Collins (COL) had its price target raised.American Airlines was upgraded to overweight from neutral and had its price target was raised to 61 from 52 at JPMorgan. The analysts also upgraded Spirit Airlines to overweight from neutral but cut the budget carrier's price target to 45 from 56.The analyst Jamie Baker wrote that American's management should have a more aggressive focus on revenue and doesn't expect a round of layoffs anytime soon as labor efficiency and productivity improve.On Monday, Cowen upgraded American, saying the airline's outlook for next year was "compelling" as it segments more of its products.Last week, American reported strong Q2 results but predicted weaker unit revenue, as did Spirit.American shares rose 1.2% to 51.06 on the stock market today. Spirit jumped 5% to 40.79.Baird downgraded Regeneron to underperform. Shares tumbled 3.4% Monday after French partner Sanofi said sales of eczema drug Dupixent fell short of expectations.Regeneron fell 4% to 472 on Tuesday, tumbling below its 50-day moving average.Rockwell Collins was upgraded to buy at Canaccord Genuity and had its price target raised to 125 from 108.But Rockwell could face increased competition from Boeing (BA) as Boeing enters the avionics space. On Monday, Boeing said it has already started work on building aircraft controls and electronics for military, civil and space vehicles. The aviation giant is just working on components for its own aircraft first but will eventually start selling to other aviation companies.Canaccord analyst Ken Herbert wrote that while the Boeing announcement "could represent a long-term risk, we believe COL is relatively well protected in the markets" and that Rockwell has a "very strong reputation with both Boeing and Airbus as a top-preforming supplier."Rockwell shares rose 4.4% to 111.18 to 107.30 after plunging 6.3% on Monday. Boeing fell 1.25%.Discovery's (DISCA) price target was lowered to 28 from 30 at FBR & Co., after announcing Monday that it would buy Scripps Networks (SNI) for about $11.9 billion, in a deal that would give the company nearly one-fifth of all ad-supported television.Discovery slid 0.9% to 24.38 after tumbling 8.2% on Monday.RELATED: The Risk To Facebook You Overlooked; Why American Air Is 'Compelling'

Boeing (BA) sees its highest demand ever for aircraft in India, as Asia continues to dominate traffic growth, but China still leads in overall, long-term demand.XThe aerospace giant expects Indian carriers to order up to 2,100 new planes, valued at $290 billion, over the next two decades. Demand will mostly be single-aisle 737 and 737 Max jets, as demand for point-to-point travel increases.Traffic in South Asia is expected to grow 8% over the next 20 years, outpacing the global average of 4.7% as well as China's growth of 6.2%, according to Boeing.Boeing shares were up 1.1% at 243.81 in midday trading on the stock market today, after surging 13.7% last week on strong earnings to enter profit-taking sell territory. Boeing is also reportedly creating a new avionics business, according to Bloomberg, hitting shares of aerospace supplier Rockwell Collins (COL), which is down 3%. Honeywell (HON) is up 0.4%, and U.S.-listed shares of Airbus (EADSY) were down 2%.Last year, India relaxed rules about domestic carriers flying abroad and pushed flights to smaller cities by capping fares that allowed low-cost carriers to flourish.Indian budget airlines have been busy placing orders in recent years, and during the Paris Air show in June, Boeing announced a SpiceJet order for 40 new 737 Max 10 planes.But China still dominates overall demand. Boeing estimated last year that the country would need 6,810 airplanes, valued at $1 trillion, over the next 20 years.The company says airlines have been adding capacity and point-to-point services to meet demand for leisure and business travel as the ranks of the middle class grow in China and around Asia.Boeing is building a completion plant in China to help keep market share as Airbus and domestic aerospace companies look to expand in the world's first trillion-dollar commercial aircraft market.RELATED: Boeing Puts Midrange Demand At 2,000-4,000 Planes; Stock Hits Sell Sign

Honeywell (HON) touted its aerospace business as being "in a great position in a growing industry," amid pressure from an activist investor who argues it would perform better as a spinoff.In a presentation at the Electrical Products Group conference in Florida Tuesday, Honeywell said increasing global flight hours, new aircraft ramping up and improving worldwide defense budgets offer "further runway" for margin expansion.Honeywell's aerospace investments totaled $2.5 billion in 2016 and are expected to climb in 2017. Over 15% of Honeywell sales are channeled into aerospace research and development — two times as much as its closest rivals, the company said.However, Third Point's Dan Loeb has said the aerospace unit has been a laggard relative to industry peers and that a spinoff would boost stock valuations and increase shareholder value by more than $20 billion.Honeywell had already been conducting a strategic review of its portfolio and said Tuesday it is "modeling various scenarios," with its assessment to wrap up by this fall.Honeywell stock rose 1 cent to 131.85 in afternoon trade on the stock market today, still in buy range after clearing a 127.62 entry last month. Among other big industrials with aerospace businesses, General Electric (GE) climbed 0.35%, United Technologies (UTX) edged up 0.3%, and Rockwell Collins (COL) lost 0.1%.New leadership at Honeywell may work in Third Point's favor, according to RBC Capital Markets, which said in a note last month that "new CEOs are often more willing to rethink an organization's portfolio." Darius Adamczyk took over as Honeywell's CEO and president in April.Honeywell, which makes airplane engines and other aircraft parts, cut its full-year sales forecast in January, citing weaker demand in corporate jets amid global trepidation about the economy and less traction in defense.However, the supplier to Boeing (BA) and Airbus (EADSY) beat first-quarter earnings expectations last month. But the aerospace segment's revenue slipped 4% to $3.55 billion, while overall sales were flat at $9.49 billion.RELATED:A Honeywell Aerospace Spinoff Could Hinge On ThisActivist Investor Third Point Urges Honeywell To Spin Off Aerospace UnitDow Stock GE May Have Headed Off Activist Investor Fight With This Move

Douglas A. Munro both followed and set an example. His first role model was his mother, Edith, and he would eventually be hers. Munro, a U.S. Coast Guard signalman first class during World War II, remains the only member of the guard to receive the Medal of Honor, the nation's highest military decoration.Munro received the medal for his actions on Guadalcanal in the Solomon Islands in late September 1942, as he directed the evacuation of 500 stranded Marines from a beach. The Marines were under heavy fire from a larger-than-expected enemy force."To Doug Munro, honor was not situational; he made it a daily habit, and demonstrated honor with every value choice he made," said Kris Cotariu Harper, an educational consultant who works with Patriots Point Naval & Maritime Museum in South Carolina. "This honor is seen in his devotion to duty, his loyalty to his mission and his comrades in arms, by his refusal to leave them on the beach at the mercy of the enemy."Raymond Evans, a retired Coast Guard Commander and Navy Cross recipient who met Douglas Munro the day they both enlisted, served with him and became his best friend, said for a USCG oral history project:"Doug was a vital, outgoing young man who liked everybody he met. … He was a hard worker and we studied together to become proficient as Coast Guard signalmen. We didn't want the Navy battleship signalmen to think we couldn't compete."Munro was born in 1919 in Vancouver, British Columbia, and grew up in Cle Elum, Wash. He was the youngest of two children born to Edith and her husband James."The fact that Edith raised a son with Doug's honor and integrity speaks to her own honor and integrity," Harper said.Douglas Munro enlisted in the Coast Guard in 1939, some two years before the United States officially entered World War II."He said, `What I like about the Coast Guard is fundamentally their reason for being is to save lives,' " Edith Munro recalled in a 1982 interview for the television show "Real People."Munro volunteered for duty on board the USCG cutter Spencer. "Doug pursued opportunities to educate himself in all areas of military need and was first to volunteer for hazardous duty situations," Harper said.In June 1941, President Roosevelt ordered the Coast Guard to man four large naval transports and its men to serve with Navy crewman aboard 18 ships.Evans said that when word came that signalmen were needed on the transport ship USS Hunter Liggett, he and Munro spent several days making their case to the Spencer's executive office to be reassigned — and were.In April 1942, four months after the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor, Hawaii, and the United States' entry into World War II, the Hunter Liggett set sail to New Zealand in preparation for combat in the South Pacific.After military successes at the battles of the Coral Sea and Midway, the Navy moved to counter the Japanese advances in the Solomon Islands. As U.S. forces advanced, the island of Guadalcanal, some 600 miles east of New Guinea, became a strategic target due to a vital airfield that the Japanese were building.On August 7, 11,000 Marines came ashore in Coast Guard-manned transports at Lunga Point, located on Guadalcanal's northern coast. They encountered little enemy resistance.Munro was now "the best small-boat operator on the island," wrote Gary Williams in his book about him, "Guardian of Guadalcanal." Munro helped transport troops to Tulagi Island, which was 20 miles across a channel from Guadalcanal. This was a much more contested landing and it took several days to secure that island.Munro was then assigned to what was now Lunga Point Base. It was a staging area for troop transports and landing craft up and down the Guadalcanal coast.In a bloody and critical battle, the U.S. quickly seized the airfield on Guadalcanal, but the Japanese kept fighting to regain control. A month after the landings, the Marines planned to advance west across the Matanikau River in order prevent the Japanese from attacking American positions.After several attempts that encountered strong Japanese resistance, on Sept. 27 three Marine companies under the command of legendary Marine Lt. Col. "Chesty" Puller planned to land west of the river to attack the Japanese and establish a patrol base.Two weeks shy of his 23rd birthday, Munro, along with Evans, was in charge of 10 landing craft: LCVPs, which carried vehicles and personnel, and LCTs, which carried tanks. The boats were slow, and the LCVPs were each equipped with only two .30-caliber machine guns.Some 600 Marines were landed and made their way inland 500 yards, but then their artillery cover from the destroyer U.S.S. Monssen was compromised by Japanese bombers. The ship was forced out of range and couldn't help protect the landed Marines, who were now at the mercy of a sizable Japanese force.Back at the Lunga Point base, where Munro and Evans had returned, Williams describes Coast Guard Cmdr. Dwight H. Dexter as running toward them to ask: " 'Are you ready to go back and get those jarheads off that beach?' 'They are getting hit pretty hard.' Munro looked at Evans and said, 'Hell, yeah!'"Both men turned and ran back down the pier, yelling to the other boat crews to get ready to depart," Williams wrote. "With Munro and Evans in the lead, the squadron headed back out to sea."As they approached the landing point, the Japanese unleashed a barrage of mortar and automatic-weapons fire on the boats that Munro was leading back to the beach, resulting in casualties. One of the boats pulled up alongside Munro's and its crew yelled to him that the attempt to rescue the Marines was too dangerous."Munro responded by jabbing his finger toward the beach and yelled, 'We're not leavin' them there! We're goin' in!' " Williams wrote.Waves of haggard Marines emerged from the dense jungle dragging wounded and dead comrades. Two to three landing craft at a time picked them up as Munro and Evans provided machine-gun cover. Then Munro maneuvered their boat to act as a shield between Japanese fire from a ridge and the withdrawing men.One blood-covered Marine said to Evans, "You came back, thank God." Evans pointed to Munro.Having directed the evacuation of some 500 Marines, Munro and Evans were headed for Lunga Point when they saw that an LCT loaded with Marines was grounded on a nearby beach.According to Evans, Munro then directed an LCT to go in, use a tow line, and free the ship and men from the beach. The procedure took about 20 minutes and there was no gunfire from the Japanese or sight of them there.As the landing craft headed out to sea, Evans "saw a line of waterspouts coming across the water from where the LCT had been grounded and realized it was machine-gun fire" from a Japanese emplacement. He yelled, "Doug, get down!""I don't think Munro saw the line of bullets since he was facing forward and did not at first react to my yelling over the engine noise," Evans said.Munro received a mortal wound at the base of his skull. Munro's final words summed up his short life of service; he wanted to know about the last detachment of Marines on the beach, asking, "Did we get them off?""And they said `Yes Doug, we did,' " Edith Munro recalled in her 1982 TV appearance. "They said he just beamed. And then he died.""Munro was recommended for the Medal of Honor by the United States Marine Corps, and his portrait is (of) the only non-Marine displayed in the National Museum of the Marine Corps Hall of Heroes," Williams said.The medal was presented to his parents in the Oval Office by President Franklin Roosevelt. His citation reads, in part, "For extraordinary heroism and conspicuous gallantry in action above and beyond the call of duty as Officer-in-Charge … in the evacuation of a Battalion of Marines trapped by enemy Japanese forces at Point Cruz, Guadalcanal." In addition to his Medal of Honor, Munro also received the Purple Heart.But the story didn't end with Douglas Munro's death. Williams told IBD that when Edith Munro learned that the Coast Guard had created a women's auxiliary known as the SPARS, which stands for "semper paratus: always ready," she attempted to enlist to fulfill her son's commitment."The Coast Guard was reticent to allow the enlistment of a Medal of Honor Gold Star mother and offered her an advanced-rank commission, lieutenant junior grade," Williams said. "She accepted the commission on condition she be permitted to complete basic training with all other recruits. At the age of 48, twice the age of her fellow recruits, she completed basic training and became the first female officer assigned to a district commander's staff."The high-endurance cutter USCGC Munro, commissioned in 1971, was named in Douglas Munro's honor. Edith Munro, in her mid-70s, was on hand for the ceremony, just as she had been in 1944 when a Navy destroyer escort was named for her son.And in November 2013 the U.S. Coast Guard headquarters in Washington, D.C., was named the Douglas A. Munro Coast Guard Building by an act of Congress.Only member of the United States Coast Guard to receive the Medal of Honor. Recipient of the Purple Heart. USCGC Munro, commissioned in 1971, named in his honor.Overcame: Intense enemy fire to rescue Marines stranded during the Battle of Guadalcanal.Lesson: Take your training seriously, and your duty."Doug Munro did not become a hero at his moment of valor. He prepared for that moment his entire life. And when that moment came, he unhesitatingly did what needed to be done, at the cost of his own life." — Kris Cotariu HarperMORE ABOUT LEADERS & SUCCESS:Peter Tomich's Sacrifice Saved Hundreds Of Lives At Pearl HarborJimmy Doolittle Wrecked Japan's Invincible ImageEddie Rickenbacker's Daring, Determination Took Him To Aviation's Heights

China successfully completed the first test flight of its home-built modern passenger jet, bolstering President  Xi Jinping's ambition of turning China into an advanced economy.Amid cheers from onlookers, the C919 airliner took off Friday from Pudong International Airport in Shanghai, the home base of its builder Commercial Aircraft Corp. of China Ltd., or Comac. The jet landed back about an hour and 19 minutes later after cruising at 3,000 meters (9,840 feet). The single-aisle plane, which is designed to seat as many as 174 people, is slated to enter commercial service with China Eastern Airlines Corp. in 2019."It shows China made a historic breakthrough in its years-old dream of building a big aircraft," Comac said in a statement, calling the test a "complete success." The nation's State Council, the top administrative authority, sent a congratulatory note to the designers.The test flight, after repeated delays, marks another step in Xi's ambitious 'Made in China 2025' program, which identified aerospace among sectors that could accelerate China's advancement. The government has said the ability to build and fly a large commercial aircraft is the "flower'' and "pearl'' of modern manufacturing.The C919 would be the first major competitor for Airbus SE and Boeing Co. in the most popular sector of the airliner market and gives Comac a home advantage in what is set to become the world's biggest aircraft market. Boeing estimates China will need 6,810 aircraft worth more than $1 trillion in the two decades through 2035."There's a lot riding on the C919,'' said Xu Yongling, a military test pilot and a member of the Beijing-based Chinese Society of Aeronautics and Astronautics. "The expectation for the C919 is not to become the best-selling single-aisle aircraft in the market, but rather become a stepping stone for COMAC to build something better, with indigenous technology.''COMAC plans to make six planes for tests, and the second one is getting ready at the final assembly workshop in Shanghai, the builder said. Guests who witnessed Friday's test flight included Vice Premier Ma Kai and Han Zheng, Communist Party secretary from Shanghai.The five people on board the test plane were the captain, co-pilot, an observer and two engineers.Getting into the major league with Airbus (EADSY) and Boeing (BA) may be a few decades away as customers typically prefer aircraft with proven track record, reliability and safety, analysts said. COMAC is seeking certification for the C919 from European agencies."Comac could well be an option for us," said William Walsh, chief executive officer of IAG SA, the owner of British Airways Plc, adding he'd only seriously consider the plane when IAG reviews its existing fleet of short-haul Airbus A320-family jets in the long-term. More immediately, he's expecting lower prices from the added competition.Walsh, a former pilot who's flown in the plane's simulator, said he's due to meet with Comac next month to further advise on features that IAG looks for in a new model."A new entrant will have an impact on pricing," Walsh told analysts on a call Friday. "We've seen that to some degree with the launch of the CSeries. It's something that both airlines and the manufacturers are aware of."The C919 designation was chosen partly to reflect the idea of long life in Chinese numerology.With a maximum range of 3,450 miles, the plane is powered by two LEAP-1C engines from CFM International Inc., a joint venture between Safran SA and General Electric (GE). Other key system suppliers include Honeywell International (HON), Rockwell Collins (COL), Liebherr-International Deutschland GmbH, Thales SA and Panasonic Corp.The test flight of the plane follows China's launch last month of its first domestically built aircraft carrier. The milestones, coming within weeks, burnish Xi's credentials as a modernizer before he presides over the ruling Communist Party's twice-a-decade congress later this year.Almost a billion people will fly to, from or within China by 2025, the International Air Transport Association estimates. Over the next two decades, about 75 percent of the jets ferrying those passengers will be single-aisle -- a category dominated by Boeing's 737 and Airbus's A320 family.In an email, Boeing congratulated Comac for the "successful development" of the C919, while Airbus said it welcomes competition, "which is good for the development of the industry."Comac, which had postponed the test flight at least twice, says it has commitments from 23 customers for about 570 planes, with Shanghai-based China Eastern lined up to take the first delivery.Richard Aboulafia, an aerospace analyst at Teal Group, said China may have to wait till its next aircraft to really break the duopoly for jets that can carry more than 100 passengers."At the moment, they are in a real replication mode, which is not where you want to be," he said. "First off, they need to privatize and open their supply chain up to a global network, rather than just people who will transfer yesterday's technology."Comac has set its sights on building a wide-body aircraft. It is forming a joint venture with Russia's United Aircraft Corp. to develop a twin-aisle jet."The C919 is a testament to China's civil aviation research and manufacturing capability," said Yu Zhanfu, executive director at Roland Berger Management Consultants Shanghai Co. "China's had a lot of success in making rockets, making spaceships. It shows the country is capable of mega tech-intensive manufacturing projects."

Third Point, the activist hedge fund run by Dan Loeb, reportedly has issued a letter calling for Honeywell (HON) to spin off its aerospace unit, which is the industrial conglomerate's largest segment by revenue.Loeb says Honeywell's stock trades at a "substantial discount" to its peers and that an aerospace spinoff would produce a "sustained increase in shareholder value" of more than $20 billion, according to the New York Times.Shares of Honeywell jumped 3.2% to 134.00 in after-hours trading on the stock market today. The stock remains near record highs after topping first-quarter earnings forecasts last week.Shares of General Electric (GE), which has been under pressure from Trian Fund Management to improve results, edge up 0.1% late to 29.10. United Technologies (UTX) wasn't active late but closed up 0.5% at 118.78. Rockwell Collins (COL) was also quiet after falling 0.6% to 104.48.In February, Third Point disclosed a new stake in Honeywell. In its letter Thursday, it said several Wall Street analysts are in favor of a spinoff, the Times reported.Honeywell's wide array of aerospace products include gas turbine auxiliary power units and cockpit systems and displays. In Q1, the segment's revenue slipped 4% to $3.55 billion, though on an organic basis it was flat.

Lockheed Martin's (LMT) F-35 flew alongside older fighters from the U.S. and allied forces during its recent European deployment, providing the Air Force with new lessons on how the stealth jet can be supported and integrated with other forces.Pentagon officials envision "fifth-generation" F-35s and F-22s entering a battle space first to suppress any airborne or air-defense threats, allowing older, but more heavily armed "fourth-generation" fighters to follow.X Eight Air Force F-35A variants from the 34th Fighter Squadron deployed to RAF Lakenheath in the U.K. in April and were later sent to Estonia and Bulgaria as a show of force in the region and to test the procedures and logistics of moving the F-35 around the area.While the F-35 didn't fly with any Bulgarian or Estonian aircraft, they did train with U.S. Boeing (BA) F-15s stationed at Lakenheath and flew with British, Dutch and Norwegian Lockheed F-16s.The last of the F-35s returned to the U.S. on May 9, and officials from Hill Air Force Base offered more details Wednesday about the plane's first deployment to Europe."We continue to learn again and again that the 5th gen is making our 4th gen more survivable, and the 4th gen makes us more lethal or deadly with their fire power," Lt. Col. George Watkins, the 34th Fighter Squadron commander, told reporters during a briefing.Here are some other takeaways:Lockheed shares were down 0.8% at 269.51 in late-afternoon trading on the stock market today, dipping below their 270 buy point amid a broad sell-off. United Technologies, whose Pratt & Whitney unit makes the plane's engines, dropped 1.6%, re-entering the high end of its buy zone. Northrop, a major F-35 subcontractor, dipped 0.1% to 247.18 but still near a 249.53 entry.As tensions heat up in the region, Germany could be the next NATO ally to buy the F-35 outside current NATO partner countries like the U.K., the Netherlands, Norway, Turkey and Italy.According to a Reuters report Wednesday, the German air force requested classified data on the F-35 as it looks to start replacing its older fourth-generation jets between 2025 and 2035. There are no plans yet for a procurement program from Berlin.The F-35 will attend the Paris Air Show next month, but Lockheed, not the Air Force, will get the plane over to the show.RELATED:The Brains For Lockheed's F-35 Just Got SmarterLockheed's F-35, F-22 May Soon Face Their Moment Of Truth

XDow Jones industrial average component General Electric (GE) on Friday turned out first-quarter earnings that topped analyst estimates. But shares fell, potentially due the state of the company's industrial operating cash flow, which turned negative and was a billion worse than the company expected.Meanwhile, fellow diversified industrial giant Honeywell (HON) also topped first-quarter earnings forecasts, soaring to a record high and briefly hitting a new entry area.General Electric's industrial cash flow from operating activities was negative $1.6 billion, partly due to the timing of things like cash collection for service contracts. But the company held to its forecast for the metric of between $12 billion to $14 billion this year."That single point, which is very important for quality of earnings, simply gave investors a reason not to feel good about the quarter," RBC analyst Deane Dray said.Analysts have focused more on General Electric's cash flow since its separation from its finance arm, GE Capital, he said. That move, done to help GE return to its industrial roots, enabled Wall Street to more closely scrutinize GE's core finances.The company, he said, spent a good deal talking about the cash-flow situation — perhaps too much."You end up sounding more defensive the more you talk about it," Dray said.Questions were also raised about whether General Electric can reach a $1 billion cost-cutting goal this year.In a research note after GE reported results, Cowen analyst Gautam Khanna said several factors — including negative industrial cash flow, and GE's cost-cutting plans — "may mitigate the stock's reaction today."General Electric also only tallied $76 million worth of savings toward the $1 billion target, part of an agreement worked out with activist investor Trian Fund Management. However, management on the company's earnings call said the pace of cost cutting would accelerate through the year.In March, following what Trian characterized as "intensified" discussions, the fund and General Electric worked out an agreement in which GE would try to slash $2 billion from its industrial segment this year and next. Executive bonuses would be tied to whether it meets those goals.GE also stuck with its full-year earnings-per-share forecast of $1.60-$1.70 and organic growth of 3%-5%.Shares fell 2.4% to 29.55 in the stock market today, undercutting their 50-day line a day after finding upside resistance at the 200-day line.GE has been mired in what has been called an "industrial recession" in which slow growth and an oil glut have affected demand for its equipment.While the company in January said that oil markets were stabilizing, management said Friday that "a large degree of uncertainty remains," with stockpiles still flush with crude and OPEC's deliberations over keeping a lid on production hanging over oil prices.U.S. crude oil futures sank 2.2% to $49.62 a barrel, part of a 7.4% weekly tumble."GE had a good quarter in a slow growth and volatile environment," Chairman and CEO Jeff Immelt said on the company's earnings call. "While the resource sector is challenging, we had the strongest oil & gas orders in 10 quarters." Oil and gas revenue dropped 9% to $3 billion.Immelt said that the company sees "global growth accelerating while the US continues to improve," and that China, Africa, Latin America and Southeast Asia were "all stronger than last year."General Electric's EPS was flat at 21 cents on revenue of $27.66 billion, down less than 1% vs. a year earlier, topping views for 17 cents and $26.405 billion, respectively. Organic revenue climbed 7% and organic orders climbed 10%.Revenue for GE's aviation segment, which makes jet engines and other equipment, grew 9% to $6.08 billion. Revenue in power systems, which include gas turbines, rose 17% to $6.09 billion.Renewable energy revenue jumped 22% to $2.04 billion. Health care edged up 3% to $4.29 billion, helped by China, whose middle class has expanded.Within the health care division, which offers surgical imaging, ultrasound technology and an array of other products, GE remained upbeat on the global health care market, even as Republicans in Congress try to revive efforts to repeal the Affordable Care Act."GE is continuing its portfolio transformation and investing in innovations in GE Digital and GE Additive," said Immelt in a statement. "Our planned combination of GE Oil & Gas and Baker Hughes remains on track, and we expect the deal to close in mid-2017."The deal with oilfield services firm Baker Hughes, which does much of its work on land, could broaden General Electric's exposure to the oil recovery as rig activity picks up in the Permian Basin and elsewhere. Much of GE's business in oil and gas is in deep-sea drilling.Investors have grown more cautious about the probability of President Trump and Congress delivering on tax reform and other policy goals quickly, though Trump told AP on Friday that a "massive tax cut" package will be released next week. Upcoming elections in Europe have also stirred anxiety.Honeywell's EPS rose 11% to $1.66 excluding divestitures on revenue of $9.492 billion, just below a year earlier. Organic revenue climbed 2%. The maker of avionics gear and climate control products also raised the low end of its full-year EPS target range by 5 cents and now sees $6.90-$7.10, up 7%-10%.Shares rose as high as 128.30, a record high and above a 127.62 flat base buy point. Honeywell closed up 2.7% at 127.07.Rockwell Collins (COL), a maker of aircraft parts, offered a full-year EPS forecast of $4.50-$4.70, one that was affected by its recent acquisition of B/E Aerospace, according to Reuters. However, Rockwell raised its sales outlook to $6.7 billion-$6.8 billion. B/E Aerospace provides products and services for aircraft interiors.Rockwell shares shot up 5.1% to 104.70, hitting a record high.RELATED:Honeywell Cuts 2017 Sales Outlook, Citing Drop In Jet Sales

Following recent minimum-wage setbacks in Baltimore, Flagstaff, Ariz., and Miami Beach, the Fight for $15 is attempting today to regain its momentum for raising the minimum wage — with another round of coordinated protests in major cities nationwide.This marks at least the twelfth coordinated Fight for $15 protest paid for by the Service Employees International Union since 2012. To keep the protest fresh for the media and ensure its quota of sympathetic news stories, the Fight for $15 has partnered with the activist group Black Lives Matter."What we both realize is we're stronger when we operate together," says Fight for $15 organizing director Kendell Fells.It's a strange association for many reasons. For unions, which have spent upward of $100 million on the Fight for $15 in recent years, they risk alienating some of their more centrist supporters by partnering with a group built on the misconception that there is an epidemic of racially motivated police shootings.But the association is even weirder for Black Lives Matter, given the role of minimum-wage increases in creating additional barriers to black employment.A recent review of minimum-wage research by economists at the San Francisco Federal Reserve concludes, "A higher minimum wage results in some job loss for the least-skilled workers — with possibly larger adverse effects than earlier research suggested." Because they often face failing public schools and divided families, black job-seekers are often less skilled than their counterparts and are disproportionately impacted by such entry-level wage increases.According to a report last year by the nonpartisan Congressional Budget Office, roughly one in three black men aged 18 to 34 is either jobless or incarcerated. Among those without a high school education, that figure approaches two in three. The CBO cites the numerous recent minimum-wage increases at the state and local level as a cause of this employment carnage.Ironically, unemployment among black youth is worst in the cities where Fight for $15 and Black Lives Matter are protesting today. In Philadelphia, the current rate of black teen unemployment is 27%. In Baltimore, it's 35%. In New York City and Los Angeles County, it's 33%. In metro Atlanta, where I grew up, it's 38%. And in Washington, D.C., it's 39%. In black neighborhoods in these cities the unemployment rate regularly exceeds 50%.Now is not the time to increase barriers to employment for black youth by dramatically increasing the minimum wage. Black youngsters need a job more than a raise.Why aren't these staggering black unemployment statistics common knowledge? Because for minimum-wage or black activists to acknowledge them would mean admitting that the minimum wage has nothing to do with the problems facing the black community. In fact, to the extent that the minimum wage keeps black people out of the workforce, it exacerbates their problems.Such an admission would mean having to tackle issues facing black communities today that are not politically correct. These include divided families, broken public schools, gang violence and a lack of entrepreneurial opportunity.Rather than supporting counterproductive increases to the wage floor, activists should fight to raise the wage ceiling for average job-seekers. In other words, fight for $50,000-a-year careers, not $15-an-hour mandates. Fight for victors, not victims.This is not a far-fetched goal. Roughly half of the current 5.6 million unfilled jobs nationally pay this amount or more. These include hundreds of thousands of jobs in fields like sales, maintenance and trades.But before job-seekers can get these good jobs, they first need jobs in which they can gain a toehold on the bottom rung of the career ladder and learn soft skills like customer-service, communication, and camaraderie to quickly move up it. For black youths, who often don't get this training at home or in the classroom, this is especially important.As Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen highlighted in her speech to the National Community Reinvestment Coalition last week, the research connection between entry-level jobs and career prospects is robust. To win the fight for $50,000, these jobs must be protected.The black community has many issues to protest about today. The minimum wage is not one of them.RELATED: Minimum Wage Is Racist, Kills Jobs And Doesn't Help The Poor — Apart From That, It's A Great Idea 'Fight For $15': The Most Devastating Minority Job-Killer Ever?

Stocks opened slightly lower Friday as a heavy slate of earnings reports failed to stir any serious market momentum.The Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 were a fraction lower. The Dow Jones industrial average erased a small loss and was up less than 0.1%.The Nasdaq holds an easy lead for the week among the big benchmarks, trading up 1.9% through Thursday, boosted by Alphabet's (GOOGL) 2.4% gain and Amazon.com's (AMZN) 2% advance during that time. It also has been a good week overall for small caps. The Russell 2000 finished Thursday up 2.9% for the week, enough to climb back above the 50-day moving average.Amazon was and Alphabet traded flat in Friday's open.An early rally Thursday sent the Dow industrials into Friday's session toting a 0.6% gain for the week, although the index fell off late Thursday afternoon and continues to trade below its 50-day moving average.The S&P 500 ended Thursday ahead 1.2% for the week and in a serious test of resistance at its 50-day line.Rockwell Collins (COL) surged 3% and Robert Half International (RHI) fell 1.5% after their earnings reports. Schlumberger (SLB) gapped down to a loss of nearly 3% after reporting results, while Steve Madden (SHOO) rose nearly 3%.In the Dow industrials, Visa (V) rose 1% to a new high.  Visa reported stronger-than-expected second-quarter results late Thursday and steered full-year revenue guidance toward the high end of its previously stated range.General Electric (GE)  fell 0.3% after delivering larger-than-expected second-quarter earnings and a smaller-than-forecast revenue decline. The stock has been consolidating, trading below resistance at its 40-week moving average since January, as it works on a flat base.IBD 50 stock Citizen's Financial Group (CFG) was flat. A 49% earnings gain and a 14% rise in revenue reported late Thursday topped analyst targets. Shares are working to climb off the bottom of a seven-week-old consolidation.Online security services provider Proofpoint (PFPT) bolted 10% higher, although its 233% surge in first-quarter earnings reported after Thursday's close fell short of analysts expectations. A 43% revenue gain cleared targets, and full-year earnings and revenue guidance were all above consensus views.Skechers (SKX) fell 0.4%. Brokerage B. Riley upgraded the stock to buy from neutral after a first-quarter beat late Thursday, but management guided second-quarter earnings below the consensus estimate. The stock has been recovering since October, and pulled back to test support at its 40-week line for the past three weeks.S&P 500 stock Honeywell (HON) added nearly 3% as a 10% rise in earnings and flat revenue were better than projected by analysts. The aerospace and control components manufacturer is forming a flat base and is nearing a 127.62 buy point.Stanley Black & Decker (SWK) ratcheted up nearly 2%, after a 1% earnings increase and a 5% gain in revenue topped projections. The tool maker is in a buy range, rebounding from support at its 10-week moving average.Manhattan Associates (MANH) tanked 7% at the open. The developer of supply chain management software delivered mixed first-quarter results, and guided full-year revenue below consensus estimates.Mattel (MAT) tumbled 7% after its first-quarter report delivered late Thursday continued an seemingly endless series of quarterly losses. Shares remain in a multi-year correction.Oil prices rose, with West Texas Intermediate trading below $51 a barrel and down almost 5% for the week after a three-week run up. Baker-Hughes' (BHI) weekly drilling rig report is expected at 1 p.m. ET.Neel Kashkari, president of the Minneapolis Federal Reserve Bank, speaks at 9:30 a.m.ET.  Researcher Markit releases its preliminary composite purchasing managers index for April at 9:45 a.m. ET.  The National Association of Realtors reports March new home sales numbers at 10 a.m. ET.Europe's markets were uneven heading into this weekend's presidential vote in France. Frankfurt's DAX was up 0.5% in afternoon trade, while London's FTSE 100 inched up 0.1%. The CAC 40 in Paris showed 0.1% decline.RELATED:Futures Up After Trump Bump; These 3 Dow Stocks Are Near Buy PointsSchlumberger Revenue Finally Rises, But Misses Views

ARLINGTON, Va. — The Air Force looks to be "completely transparent" about its secretive new stealth bomber, at least on Capitol Hill, while the Pentagon stays tight lipped in public about Northrop Grumman's (NOC) B-21 Raider.Lt. Gen. Arnold Bunch, military deputy in Air Force acquisition, said he met with members of Congress on Wednesday to discuss a preliminary design review on the B-21 as well as provide a schedule of key milestones and other events expected with the bomber, which will replace Cold War-era Boeing (BA) B-52s.But it was unclear from Bunch's comments at an Air Force Association breakfast Thursday if his Capitol Hill discussions included cost figures, the lack of which has drawn stern warnings in the past from Senate Armed Services Chairman John McCain, R-Ariz.He has taken issue with the B-21's cost-plus contract, which puts taxpayers on the hook for any overruns, and with the Air Force's refusal to provide a full cost estimate. So far, the service has only put development costs at $23.5 billion and the per-plane cost at $564 million in 2016 dollars. Analysts, however, estimate the total acquisition price tag could hit $80 billion."Why would you not want to tell the American people how you are going to spend their dollars?" McCain asked during a hearing last year. The Air Force countered by saying it doesn't want enemies inferring the plane's capabilities based on price figures.But the B-21 isn't so secret that the Air Force won't disclose the identities of top subcontractors, who can help build more political support among lawmakers seeking Pentagon spending for their states and districts. They include United Technologies' (UTX) Pratt & Whitney, BAE Systems (BAESY) and Rockwell Collins (COL).Northrop shares were down 1.5% at 240.28 on the stock market today. United Tech slipped 0.65% to 112.34 dropping back below its buy point, and Rockwell Collins climbed 0.4%, remaining in buy range. Boeing dipped 0.3%, still above buying territory.But Bunch warned that the public shouldn't expect more information anytime soon."I don't see us releasing any more details for a period of time," he said. "We've been very open so far. We need to watch how we are communicating. Right now, we've released enough."RELATED: Air Force To Seek Proposals For Low-Cost Attack Plane ExperimentBattle Stations! Which Pentagon Programs Could Trump Attack Next?

Last week on CNN I debated a liberal commentator who complained that the problem with President Donald Trump's budget blueprint is that it lacks "compassion" for the poor, for children and for the disabled.This woman went on to ask me how I could defend a budget that would cut Meals on Wheels, after-school programs and special-education funding, because without the federal dollars, these vital services would go away.This ideology — that government action is a sign of compassion — is upside-down and contrary to the Christian notion of charity.We all, as individuals, can and should act compassionately and charitably. We can volunteer our time, energy and dollars to help the underprivileged. We can feed the hungry, house the homeless. Most of us feel a moral and ethical responsibility to do so — to "do unto others."And we do fulfill that obligation more than the citizens of almost any other nation. International statistics show that Americans are the most charitable people in the world and the most likely to engage in volunteerism.Whenever there is an international crisis — an earthquake, a flood, a war — Americans provide more assistance than the people of any other nation.But government, by its nature, is not compassionate. It can't be. It is nothing other than a force. Government can only spend a dollar to help someone when it forcibly takes a dollar from someone else.At its core, government welfare is predicated on a false compassion. This isn't to say that government should never take collective action to help people. But these actions are based on compulsion, not compassion.If every so-called "patriotic millionaire" would simply donate half of their wealth to serving others we could solve so many of the social problems in this country without a penny of new debt or taxes.My friend Arthur Brooks, the president of American Enterprise Institute, has noted in his fabulous book "Who Really Cares: The Surprising Truth About Compassionate Conservatism" that conservatives donate more than the self-proclaimed compassionate liberals.The liberal creed seems to be: "We care so much about poor people, climate change, income inequality and protecting the environment (or whatever the cause of the day) that there is no limit to how much money should be taken out of other people's wallets to solve these problems."Let's take Meals on Wheels. Is this a valuable program to get a nutritious lunch or dinner to infirmed senior citizens? Of course, yes.Do we need the government to fund it? Of course not. I have participated in Meals on Wheels and other such programs, making sandwiches or delivering hot lunches. And many tens of thousands of others donate their time and money every day for this worthy cause.Why is there any need for government here? The program works fine on its own. Turning this sort of charitable task over to government only makes people act less charitably on their own. It leads to an "I gave at the office" mentality, which leads to less generosity.It also subjects these programs to federal rules and regulations that could cripple them. Why must the federal government be funding after-school programs, or any school programs, for that matter?One of my favorite stories of American history dates back to the 19th century when Col. Davy Crockett, who fought at the Alamo, served in Congress. In a famous incident, Congress wanted to appropriate $100,000 to the widow of a distinguished naval officer.Crockett took to the House floor and delivered his famous speech, relevant as ever: "We have the right, as individuals, to give away as much of our own money as we please in charity; but as members of Congress we have no right to so appropriate a dollar of the public money. ... I am the poorest man on this floor. I cannot vote for this bill, but I will give one week's pay to the object, and if every member of Congress will do the same, it will amount to more than the bill asks."Crockett was the only member of Congress who donated personally to the widow, while the members of Congress who pretended to be so caring and compassionate closed their wallets.It all goes to show that liberal do-gooders were as hypocritical then as they are today.

Eddie Rickenbacker overcame a lot to become a fighter pilot in World War I. At 8, he had developed a fear of heights after trying to fly off the roof of his home with an umbrella attached to his bike. After becoming a famed race car driver at 27, he accepted an invitation to go up in an early plane, which scared him to death, but also thrilled him.He joined the Army hoping to join its Air Service on arrival in France in June 1917, but his skills as an engine mechanic were too valuable to allow him to allow him into the air. He sneaked in flying time, and after qualifying was allowed to go up, despite being two years over the age limit and lacking a college degree.In April 1918, Rickenbacker shot down his first enemy plane and a month later joined the 1% of combat pilots earning the title "flying ace" with his fifth confirmed kill, going on to become America's top gun of the war, with 26."He was absolutely fearless — not that he wasn't afraid, but he knew how to persist and overcome his fears," Winston Groom, author of "The Aviators: Eddie Rickenbacker, Jimmy Doolittle, Charles Lindbergh, and the Epic Age of Flight," told IBD. "He had a winning mindset and could envision the future, which was the key to his success in all his main endeavors, including auto racing and starting Eastern Air Lines."Rickenbacker (1890-1973) grew up in Columbus, Ohio, where his Swiss immigrant parents and their eight kids barely had enough to eat. At 5, Eddie got up at 4:30 a.m. to sell newspapers. When he was 13, his father died, so he dropped out of school and worked 12-hour shifts six days a week at a factory making glass tumblers.After getting a ride in an early roadster, Eddie's fascination led to a job at a repair shop for "horseless carriages." He taught himself to drive and soon was able to take apart engines and put them back together blindfolded. After taking a correspondence course in mechanics, in 1910 he was hired as the chief engineer at the Columbus Buggy Co., which made electric and gas-powered cars. He also earned the firm publicity by racing their cars on dirt tracks and earning the moniker "Fast Eddie."In 1911, taking a train to visit a rich customer, he stuck his head out the window and a cinder from a passing locomotive entered his right eye. After a painful operation without anesthesia, he was left with a permanent blind spot. But that didn't slow him down: At 24, he was a full-time race car driving earning $24,000 (equivalent to $600,000 today). He sometimes drew crowds of 50,000 and competed four times in the already world-famous Indianapolis 500."You didn't win races because you had more guts," his obituary in the New York Times quoted him as saying. "You won because you knew how to take the turns and baby your engine. It wasn't all just shut your eyes and grit your teeth."In 1914, the Great War had started in Europe, with the U.S. neutral at first."Rickenbacker had paid close attention to the news about the heroic British young men who had taken to the air to play deadly three-dimensional chess against the Red Baron and other German aces," said John F. Ross, author of "Enduring Courage: Ace Pilot Eddie Rickenbacker and the Dawn of the Age of Speed."But Army leaders weren't yet sold on the importance of aircraft, except for photo reconnaissance and turned down Rickenbacker's initial application to fly. Then in June 1917, a friend who was now an Army major invited him to become a staff sergeant and join a secret mission sailing out of New York. It turned out to be Army commander Gen. John J. Pershing and his staff, including headquarters chief Capt. George S. Patton Jr., and they needed drivers.One of those he chauffeured was Col. Billy Mitchell, whose advocacy for air combat was resisted by Army brass. Mitchell arranged to get Rickenbacker into a French flight school, despite his bad eye. In September, he was tapped to be chief engineer at the Army Air Service's combat training facility in Issoudun, France."Pilots were largely on their own, picking up insights from fellow fliers," said Ross. "Flying a plane like the Nieuport with a joystick was said to be akin to 'trying to fly a gyroscope.' This was where Rickenbacker's superior racetrack-honed instincts took over."His superiors tried to keep him repairing engines, but by Spring 1918, Rickenbacker had qualified to join the 94th Aero Squadron. Its most famous member, Raoul Lufbery, was a French expatriate who took him under his wing and taught him how to dogfight.On Sept. 25, now captain of the squadron, Rickenbacker was flying solo over Verdun on what was to become his most famous mission. In his French Spad XIII, he went after two German reconnaissance planes, dodging their gunners before shooting down one plane. Then he came under attack by five fighters and he downed one and escaped. He belatedly received the Medal of Honor for this in 1931, as well as a record eight Distinguished Service Crosses, holding the Ace of Aces title until World War II.After returning home, he founded Rickenbacker Motor in Detroit in 1920, and it soon had 600 dealerships."Rickenbacker Motors announced with great fanfare that its 1924 automobiles would include a reliable, state-of-the-art, four-wheel braking system," said Groom. "This caught the other auto companies by surprise, because they had large inventories of cars and it was too late for them to change. They ran an ad campaigning that charged, falsely, that the four-wheel braking system was unsafe, causing cars to skid out of control in rain, perhaps hurl passengers into the windshield."Rickenbacker's invention was decades ahead of its time, but the company went into a tailspin during the 1925 recession and was out of business two years later. He personally owed creditors $250,000, but instead of declaring bankruptcy, Rickenbacker eventually repaid them.Rickenbacker put together a syndicate to buy the Indiana Motor Speedway at the end of 1927. It was very profitable, but shut down during World War II to conserve fuel and he sold it in 1945.General Motors (GM) recruited Rickenbacker to help it enter aviation, including the acquisition of Fokker Aircraft and North American Aviation, an umbrella that included Eastern Air Transportation. In 1935, he merged Eastern with Florida Airways to form Eastern Air Lines, and three years later bought it from GM for $3.5 million ($59 million in today's money).Rickenbacker "ran his company in much the same manner he had commanded the 94th Squadron in World War I," his New York Times obituary said. "He set impossible goals, and then went out and achieved them himself before complaints got out of hand." And it credited him with being "the first man to prove that airlines could be made profitable, and then the first to prove that they could be run without a Government subsidy and kept profitable.""Eastern was the blue chip of the airline industry then," venture capitalist and Rickenbacker friend Laurance Rockefeller is quoted as saying in "Eastern Airlines: A History, 1926-1991. "His forte was his ability to analyze costs — that was the key to his early success."It was while traveling for business that Rickenbacker was a passenger on an Eastern flight in February 1941 that crashed in Atlanta. His injuries were so extensive that the emergency rescue team initially left him for dead and it took months for him to recover.In October 1942, Secretary of War Harold Stimson asked Rickenbacker to undertake a sensitive mission to assess the situation in the conflict's Pacific theater. Over the central Pacific, Rickenbacker and the nine crewmen went down and all but one survived for 24 days in life rafts. In 1943, he traveled to the Soviet Union and China to report on their wartime needs.Eastern Air Lines would become the most profitable commercial airline in the postwar era, but he was ousted in 1959 and it went into a tailspin after deregulation and was liquidated in 1991. Rickenbacker died two decades later at 82."It was Rickenbacker's courage in extremity that served as a model for successive generations of explorers, adventurers, and warriors and an ever vaster host of risk takers, entrepreneurs, and executives," wrote Ross. "He was many things — daredevil, tinkerer, cool risk manager, improviser, showman, tactician, and leader — but always it was his enduring courage that shone like a beacon for the better part of a century, showing America what it could be and challenging it to get here."Most successful American fighter pilot during World War I and founder of Eastern Air Lines.Overcame: Barriers to becoming a fighter pilot, business failure, physical challenges.Lesson: Intense practice and calculated risk can achieve the seemingly impossible."I can give you a six-word formula for success: Think things through, then follow through."MORE ABOUT LEADERS & SUCCESS:Igor Sikorsky's Dream Took Flight With The HelicopterJimmy Doolittle Wrecked Japan's Invincible ImageGail Halvorsen Bombed Berlin With Candy During The 1940s Airlift
