Profiles In Courage: Since 2009, a couple of Pentagon patriots have quietly been throwing up one bureaucratic obstacle after another to frustrate the president's goal to empty and close Gitmo. They are unsung heroes.With each terrorist released from the Guantanamo Bay detention camp, President Obama gets one step closer to realizing his goal of shuttering the prison before he leaves office.But the prisoner transfer process has been deliberately slowed by career military officials concerned that their subversive commander-in-chief is sacrificing national security for politics.They worry that release of al-Qaida and Taliban detainees will endanger U.S. troops in Afghanistan and elsewhere — a valid concern, seeing how Obama's own intelligence czar recently confirmed that 1 in 3 Gitmo transfers have returned to the battlefield.In a new special report, "Pentagon Thwarts Obama's Efforts to Close Guantanamo," Reuters news service is singling out two Pentagon officials, both Marines, for rebuke for blocking White House moves to release Osama bin Laden's bodyguards and other high-value al-Qaida detainees from Gitmo, and repeatedly blocking his plan to close the terrorist prison camp.Quoting White House sources, it cites Gen. John F. Kelly, head of the U.S. Southern Command, which includes Gitmo, and Ret. Col. William K. Lietzau, former deputy assistant secretary for detainee policy, as the chief opponents of Obama's traitorous prison break.The White House whines that the Pentagon officials and their staffs have sat on videotaped testimony, photos, medical files and other documents needed to secure the transfer of some of Gitmo's dangerous prisoners to Muslim countries where too often they are simply freed to rejoin the jihad against the U.S. and West.Even after the White House intervened to order the Pentagon to hand over videos to the State Department, military officials classified them "Secret/NOFORN," which means it's illegal to share the material with a foreign country. After administration officials complained and got a more lenient classification, the videos came back virtually useless. They were filmed through "dimpled glass." This is fantastic.What's more, Pentagon brass have barred foreign delegations from spending the night at Gitmo, as the delegations visit with prisoners seeking repatriation. In another example of "Pentagon intransigence," Reuters complained, officials have cut the time that the delegations can interview the terrorists whom they want to adopt.Such delays have resulted in the poor little al-Qaida terrorists spending additional "months or years" at Club Gitmo "after being approved for transfer."Yes, how terrible. They'll have to stay there longer and be "tortured" by satellite TV, state-of-the-art treadmills, elliptical trainers, soccer fields, porn-on-demand, private kitchens, prayer mats, prayer beads, prayer oils, full-menu halal (Islamicly correct) meals, imams and Islamic librarians.Instead of repudiating these military leaders for going against the president's plan, we should be honoring these patriotic obstructionists as national treasures.When Obama took office, Gitmo held 242 detainees. Only 107 remain, but they're the worst of the worst. They need to stay put, and the patriots in the Pentagon should continue to use any bureaucratic trick they can come up with to block their transfer."You're detaining them to prevent a future threat," as Lietzau says. "They are the enemy. If you were captured in war, of course you wouldn't release that person — they're still the enemy, they still want to fight you, they still want to kill you. I know of American lives that have been lost because of detainees that we have released. You detain them until the end of hostilities."Or at least until this terrorist-sympathizer leaves the Oval Office.

Edmund Hillary produced two impressive feats in his 88 years. One was becoming the first person to climb Earth's highest peak — 29,000-foot Mount Everest in the Mahalangur section of the Himalayan mountain range in Nepal and Tibet — vaulting him into the pantheon of great explorers.The second was his resolve to lead a life of charity after becoming an international celebrity at age 33. Hillary devoted much of the rest of his life to improving the lives of the Sherpa people of Nepal.Hillary, melancholic and shy, was not always comfortable under the hot glare of the media spotlight.He eventually came to embrace his celebrity, but on his terms.As Paul Little wrote in his book "After Everest: Inside the Private World of Edmund Hillary," "He shaped his celebrity to suit his values, rather than compromising his values to deal with celebrity."Edmund Percival Hillary (1919-2008) was born in Auckland, New Zealand.His mother, Gertrude, was a school teacher.His father, Percy, was a beekeeper who also ran the District News, a newspaper in nearby Tuakau, where the family moved a few years after Ed's birth.Ed had an older sister, June, and a younger brother, Rex.Peaceful DadPercy was a pacifist who instilled in his children a deep social consciousness that would inform Ed's later philanthropic work.Ed was a gifted student and skipped two school grades as a youngster. He was also, as he later described himself, a "small and rather lonely child."Ed spent much of his younger years reading adventure stories and trying to avoid the children and teachers who teased him for his gangly physique.Then it was on the college, at the University of Auckland, where he studied science and math.But his mind wandered to more rugged pursuits, and he dropped out two years later.Ed's college days were invaluable in one respect: He joined a tramping club and discovered his love of mountain climbing.After a stint flying search and rescue operations in Fiji as a navigator in the Royal New Zealand Air Force during World War II, Hillary returned home to help run his father's beekeeping business.Hillary spent the next decade developing his mountaineering skills.He climbed as often as he could, reaching the summit of peaks across New Zealand and even in Europe, which he once visited to attend his sister's wedding.His 1946 peak came at New Zealand's highest, Mount Cook.Hillary was a natural on the big rocks. He was strong, extremely fit and had extraordinary stamina and endurance. Plus, he loved the solitude that hiking and climbing afforded, and he never lost the joy of mountaineering.He once told an interviewer: "I've always regarded myself in a sense as a competent amateur. Because of that, I think a freshness has been brought to it, that every new adventure has been a new experience and great fun. I really like to enjoy my adventures."In 1953, Hillary was selected to be part of a Royal Geographical Society-Alpine Club expedition whose goal was to do what no one had: climb to the top of Mount Everest.Eight previous British expeditions had failed, but this one, led by British army Col. John Hunt, would succeed spectacularly.On that expedition, Hillary's 6-foot-5 frame proved beneficial.At 4 a.m. on May 29, Hillary and Nepalese Sherpa mountaineer Tenzing Norgay set out from camp to climb the treacherous south summit, facing toward Nepal.As Maurice Isserman, a professor at Hamilton College in Clinton, N.Y., who has written extensively on the history of mountaineering in the Himalayas, told IBD, "On the slopes of Everest, as the British expedition moved up the mountain establishing new and ever-higher camps in the spring of 1953, (Hillary) would often push to the fore, his tall, angular form seemingly eating up the mountain slope with ease, despite the great altitude."At midday, Hillary and Norgay made history by reaching Everest's peak.The two spent 15 minutes on top of the world, with Hillary burying a crucifix and Norgay filling a hole with sweets.To put Hillary's achievement in perspective, only about 1,200 of the 10,000 climbers who have tried to reach the Everest summit have succeeded, while 200 have died.Hillary approached his post-Everest life with humility."I did not consider myself knightly material," he said of being knighted by the new queen of England, Elizabeth II, soon after his triumph. "For one thing, I was far too impoverished to play the role."He was also indignant that Norgay had not also received a knighthood, instead landing the George Medal, a lesser honor.EnergizedPeter Hansen, who has written a book on the history of mountaineering, said Hillary succeeded because he was "ambitious and driven, but also modest and humble. Partly that means he was a New Zealander — willing to push himself in extreme places like the Hillary Step on Everest (now named after him), but also eager to share credit for the ascent with the whole team, especially his climbing partner Tenzing Norgay."Hillary hadn't anticipated how much his feat would change his life. "I was a bit naive, really," he told the Detroit Free Press a few years before his death. "I was just a country boy. I thought the mountaineering world would be interested, but I never dreamed that it would have that effect on people who didn't climb."Hillary married Louise Rose shortly after his Everest triumph.They had three children, Peter, Sarah and Belinda. Tragedy struck in 1975 when Louise and Belinda, then a teenager, were killed in an airplane crash.Hillary was crushed by the news, and he blamed himself because he had convinced Louise to fly against her own wishes.He was distraught for months, turning to alcohol and sleeping pills.But he recovered and found love again, marrying June Mulgrew in 1989, with whom he remained until his death 19 years later at age 88.After EverestHillary embarked on many other adventures, including reaching the South Pole by tractor in 1958 and ascending the treacherous Mount Herschel during an expedition of the Antarctic.In 1985, he and another titanic figure, first man on the moon Neil Armstrong, flew a small plane to the North Pole.The same year, Hillary became New Zealand's ambassador to India, an assignment that lasted several years.Meanwhile, he wrote or co-wrote 13 books, most of them accounts of his adventures.He also lectured widely on conservation and other issues.Hillary spent much of his post-Everest life working to improve the lives of the people of Nepal, whom he grew to admire deeply.In 1960, Hillary founded the Himalayan Trust, a nonprofit dedicated to the Sherpa people, one of the ethnic groups native to Nepal, who served as guides for Western expeditions in the Himalayas. By 2006, the trust had built 27 schools, 13 village health clinics and two hospitals, as well as numerous bridges and drinking water systems."Hillary once told me," Hansen said, "he hoped he would be remembered as much for his charitable work in the Himalayas as for his feats on Everest or Antarctica."Hillary remarked: "When I kick the bucket, I don't want memorials. I don't want statues. I just want the work to continue."He did so much to improve the lives of Nepalese that in 2003, the Asian country conferred honorary citizenship on him.Peter Hillary told Little that his dad's upbringing shaped the Everest hero's values and direction:"They were a deep, philosophical family, searching for things, for a good way of living, and I think the Himalayan Trust was his way of fulfilling that childhood experience: 'What is the right way to live? Well, I am going to build schools and hospitals in Nepal.'"

Deception: Congress has found that President Obama's cash and prisoner swap for U.S. army deserter Bowe Bergdahl was not "the best deal we could get." In fact, it was a disaster that aided our enemies and endangered U.S. lives.According to a still-unreleased investigative report by the House Armed Services Committee, the 2014 prisoner swap of Bergdahl and five Taliban kingpins held at Guantanamo was primarily a political act for the White House's own purposes, not "the best deal we could get," as the Pentagon claimed at the time. Nor was it a prisoner exchange to signal the end of hostilities, as White House sources told the press.It was all about President Obama's desire to empty out Guantanamo, a sorry bid to fulfill a campaign promise to the far left, and never mind the consequences to American security, according to the Daily Beast, which got its hands on the still-unpublished report.It also may have been a White House effort to ingratiate itself to the Taliban and forge a new alliance with the hand- and foot-chopping barbarians, by calling the war over, which at the time was a political imperative.But as an exchange, it was wildly unbalanced. Not only was it actually illegal, bypassing Congress, but the five Taliban kingpins were the worst of the worst, dangerous and malevolent terrorists.And according to one source, there was a gigantic ransom sweetener that went home with the Taliban killers as part of the deal. According to terrorism blogger Walid Shoebat, Lt. Col. Anthony Shaffer (Ret.) reported the U.S. paid $5 billion ransom as part of the deal.Meanwhile, White House National Security Advisor Susan Rice assured the public that Bergdahl had served the U.S. with distinction. The White House even held a showy ceremony feting Bergdahl's strange hippie parents from Idaho, who went on to express odd ideas about solidarity with their son.Ten months after this bizarre production, the Pentagon slapped desertion charges on Bergdahl, openly defying the White House and leaving the White House "narrative" about the noble Bergdahl and his supposedly ordinary Taliban swap-mates in tatters.Who cooked up such an appalling swap scenario? None other than the usual suspects, the National Security Council's finest. Susan Rice got the first lies out, just as she did during Benghazi scandal, calling an al-Qaida-linked terror attack the work of a mad mob.The leader of the swap plan itself was then-White House deputy national security advisor Denis McDonough, who's now Obama's chief of staff, the Beast said.As for battling the Pentagon to hold "the narrative," the point man was Deputy National Security Advisor Ben Rhodes, a creative writing major, who also authored the infamous fictitious Benghazi "talking points" that Rice expounded.All this shows what a disgrace the Bergdahl affair has become, a beyond-bad deal that was all about politics, not rescuing captive soldiers, and certainly not about winning a war or keeping Americans safe.It's a microcosm of atrocious White House policy that has failed the country time and time again.

Turkey shot down a Russian warplane near the border with northwestern Syria, drawing an angry rebuke from President Vladimir Putin and marking the first direct clash between foreign powers embroiled in the civil war.

Turkey said its planes fired after the pilots ignored repeated warnings about violating its airspace. Putin called the attack "a stab in the back from the accomplices of terrorism," saying the plane was operating over Syria and targeting terrorist groups. He said Russia "won't tolerate such crimes" but stopped short of threatening any military response against Turkey, which is a member of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, warning only of "serious consequences" for bilateral ties.NATO ambassadors were to gather in Brussels later Tuesday for a report from Turkey on the incident, the first time in decades that a member country has downed a Russian military aircraft.Russia's Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov canceled a trip to Turkey planned for Wednesday and recommended citizens avoid traveling there, citing the threat of terrorism in a country that millions of Russian tourists visit every year.'Common Evil'While global financial markets slumped on fears the shoot-down could be a sign the Syrian civil war is spiraling to a new level, political analysts in Russia and Europe said major escalation seems unlikely, given the risk of any conflict between Russia and a NATO member.Putin highlighted the need for cooperation in fighting terrorism in Syria. "We expect the international community will find the strength to join forces in the fight against a common evil," he said before talks in Sochi with Jordan's King Abdullah.The incident shows how the four-year civil war is seeping beyond Syria's borders in unpredictable ways. It also highlights the rising risks of inadvertent conflict since Russia started its military campaign on Sept. 30. While Russia and the other powers involved — including the U.S. and France — all say they're targeting Islamic State, their actions often are out of sync.Hollande TalksThe U.S., France and Turkey all seek the ouster of Syrian President Bashar al-Assad, while Russia's strikes have served to shore up his embattled regime. In the wake of the deadly terror attacks in Paris earlier this month, Putin's calls for a broad coalition against Islamic State appeared to get a boost despite skepticism in the U.S. and Europe about his real aims. Tuesday's incident may set back those hopes.French President Francois Hollande meets in Washington on Tuesday with his U.S. counterpart, Barack Obama, to discuss new joint steps to counter ISIS. Hollande comes to Moscow for talks with Putin on the same issue on Thursday.U.S. military spokesman Col. Steve Warren said the Russian plane didn't respond to Turkish warnings, while saying that the incident was a matter between Russia and Turkey.The Su-24 jet was flying one kilometer (0.6 mile) inside Syria's border when it was hit and crashed four kilometers from the line, Putin said. His Defense Ministry said it was flying back to base. Turkey released what it said were radar data that showed the plane crossing into its territory before it was shot down.The downing wasn't aimed at any specific country and was in line with its rules of engagement for violations of its airspace, a Turkish government official said by text message before Putin's comments. Turkey said it warned the plane 10 times in five minutes before its F-16 jets opened fire.Pilots KilledTurkish media reported both pilots had been killed as they parachuted by Turkmen rebels. There was no immediate Russian comment on that.Neither side is interested in an escalation, said Daniel Fiott, a researcher at the Institute for European Studies at VUB in Brussels. "They'll want to defuse the situation pretty quickly," he said, "because this is not something you want to have on top of all the problems in Syria at the moment."Analysts said Russia is likely to limit any response to non-military pressure on Turkey, so as not to risk a broader conflict with its NATO allies."The last thing that Turkey wants is to get into a sharp conflict with Russia," said Fyodor Lukyanov, head of the Moscow-based Council on Foreign and Defense Policy, a research group that advises the Kremlin. "For Russia, given its military operation in neighboring Syria, a conflict with Turkey is also not in its interests."Frants Klintsevich, deputy head of the Defense Committee in the upper house of Russia's parliament, said any direct confrontation with Turkey over the incident "would be absurd and unacceptable."Economic RetaliationIn Russia, some members of parliament called for economic retaliation. One major tour company suspended sales of packages for Turkey, citing the unstable political environment, Interfax reported. Moscow is also a major buyer of Turkish farm products and other goods, while Turkey is one of the largest buyers of Russian gas.Relations between Turkey and Russia have soured since Putin started his air strikes. Turkey has at least twice warned Russia about incursions into Turkish airspace, threatening to shoot down violators. The government has also told Russia not to target ethnic Turkmen rebels in the border region.Putin on Tuesday accused Turkey of helping ISIS by buying oil from the group and providing military protection, apparently a reference to the downing of the Russian jet.'Aggressive Leaders'"You've got two of the most aggressive leaders facing off in proximate air space trying to prove something to the folks back home," said Richard Aboulafia, an analyst at the Teal Group in Fairfax Virginia. "This is very dangerous."The last time a NATO country downed a Russian warplane was in 1953, said Joerg Forbrig, senior program director at the German Marshall Fund of the U.S. in Berlin."It was just a matter of time before something like this happened," he said, adding that the incident should lead to more cooperation on reducing the risk of inadvertent conflicts in the air over Syria.

Frederick "Fritz" Payne, a retired Marine brigadier general, died this past August at age 104. He was the oldest surviving World War II ace. Aces are fighter pilots who shoot down at least five enemy aircraft. Just 1,462 have earned the title out of over 60,000 who have flown since World War I.Payne had five solo kills and helped down one other Japanese aircraft over Guadalcanal in his F4F Wildcat."The speed of our planes and the Japanese bombers we called Bettys was about the same, and you'd try to get to a high altitude and then roll down and strafe the entire plane as you came from above," Payne said in a videotaped interview in 2010 at the Palm Springs Air Museum in California. "The Zeros were faster, and if one got behind you, the best evasive action was to cut the throttle and they'd overshoot you."The almost daily aerial combat, three major land battles and seven large naval clashes from August 1942 to February 1943 cost over 7,000 American lives and 31,000 Japanese, ending the empire's expansion.High Stakes"It could have gone either way, though," Michael Myers, author of "The Pacific War and Contingent Victory: Why Japanese Defeat Was Not Inevitable," told IBD. "The Japanese came very close to taking the vital airfield. They were more successful than the U.S. in surface naval actions at night and an even match in the carrier battles of the Eastern Solomons and Santa Cruz. But the Americans had the edge in the air war."Payne was born in 1911 in Elmira, N.Y. His father was a graduate of the U.S. Naval Academy and participated in the Spanish-American War's Battle of Manila Bay.Payne entered Annapolis in 1930 but left two years later as the Depression affected his family and he moved with them near San Diego.He became interested in flying while watching planes at Coronado's naval station. He was told that if he earned a degree while serving in the Reserve Officer Training Corps, he could qualify as a pilot, so he completed his studies in 1935 at the University of Arizona in Tucson.From there he entered the Marines' aviation program as a second lieutenant at a base in Pensacola, Fla., flying Boeing F4B biplanes.After training in maneuvers at Quantico, Va., he returned to Coronado, then shipped off to Hawaii.By July 1941, Payne was back in Coronado flying the Brewster Buffalo with Marine Fighting Squadron 221. It was scheduled to ship out to the base on Midway in the Pacific on Dec. 8 when the Japanese hit Pearl Harbor the day before.Payne and his fellow Marines were ordered to reinforce Wake Island but had to turn back when it fell to the Japanese on Dec. 23.Soon, Payne became executive officer of the newly organized VMF-212, in charge of training with Grumman Wildcats in the New Hebrides Islands, 500 miles southeast of Guadalcanal.In September 1942, with Payne now a major, the carrier Wasp brought the squadron within 300 miles of Guadalcanal.The team flew to Henderson Field, and shortly after takeoff, a submarine sank the Wasp.With the Marines at the airfield under constant incoming fire, Payne took to the sky to thwart enemy planes. At 25,000 feet, his guns froze; he returned to base and waited days for them to be fixed.By late in the month, Henderson had 71 aircraft vs. the 117 that the Japanese could fly from their base 600 miles away. Payne's new outfit, VMF-223, took to the air and encountered 25 bombers protected by 30 Zeros."He picked out a bomber toward the tail of the formation and closed to effective range," wrote Max Brand in "Fighter Squadron at Guadalcanal." "He watched it fall apart. ... Suddenly, another came in from the rear, so close they nearly collided, and he barely had time to squeeze the trigger and get in one burst at the second plane."The sky is like that in war; now empty as a desert, now full of whale-shaped bombers, now alive with fighters as quick and savage as thin-sided barracuda."Payne prepared for another go at the formation when he realized the rest of the Marine squadron had left. He was given shared credit for the first bomber, which another pilot had also hit, when he got back to the base.Later in the week Payne knocked down his first solo bomber kill. "They were our priority because they were killing our troops on the ground," he said.Soon he came down with malaria with a torrid temperature, and it almost did what the enemy couldn't.At 27,000 feet, he vomited into his oxygen mask and blacked out.When he came to, the plane was at 8,000 feet and falling fast, but he managed to pull out. That was it for a while — he was shipped off to a hospital for a couple of weeks.InvasionThe next month, October 1942, the Japanese bombarded Henderson and landed 15,000 troops, bringing their total to 20,000 vs. 23,000 Allies. "We would dig foxholes as deep as we could and then try to find a piece of iron to put on top to protect us from shrapnel," Payne said. "We were really scared at night, when their ships would start shelling us."In the Oct. 18-23 period, Payne was back with the 212. He downed two more bombers and was victorious in dogfights with two Zeros."Fritz described these as free-for-alls, a type of combat in which numerous planes are zooming about, and he was making evasive moves and turning in an effort to get an enemy in his sites and squeeze off a few shots before losing him," said Bob Andrade, an aviation historian and longtime friend. "Another time he pulled the trigger, but his guns failed. His plane often returned full of holes."Meanwhile, Payne took over as the 212's commander when Lt. Col. Joe Bauer was killed on Oct. 16, and he served until February 1943.But Payne had to leave Guadalcanal on Oct. 27, 1942, to be treated for malaria, with quinine scarce.The squadron followed him to California, stationed at El Toro Marine Air Base, where Payne was promoted to lieutenant colonel.In early 1943, Payne and three other airmen met Brand to discuss writing a book about their experience. Brand was the pen name of Frederick Faust, the author of popular novels and movie screenplays.He worked on the book until his death while serving as a war correspondent in Italy in May 1944, when the manuscript disappeared.Wedding And FamilyIn 1949 — four years after war's end — Payne was stationed at the Presidio in San Francisco and married Dorothy, a Navy widow, and adopted her two children. They would have one child together.During the Korean War in 1952, Payne took charge of a forward radar control group and flew Corsairs and AD-6s seeking to destroy radar sites. He then was a liaison officer with the 5th Air Force in Seoul.The war ended in 1953, and two years later Payne took command of a helicopter squadron in Tustin, Calif. He finished his career as tactical air commander during atomic testing and retired from active duty as a brigadier general in 1958.In addition to being recognized as an ace, he was awarded the Navy Cross for his actions at Guadalcanal, the second highest honor for valor. He also received the Legion of Merit, the Distinguished Flying Cross and a Silver Star.Payne worked for Southern California Edison for 24 years, managing its aircraft and helicopter field operations before retiring in 1976. He and Dorothy lived in Rancho Mirage until she died in 2011.Before he was killed, Brand had given a copy of his manuscript to a member of the 212, Capt. Mel Freeman, and it eventually reached Payne and Andrade. They contacted Brand's daughter, Jane Faust Easton, who discovered that she had another version, and she and her husband completed the final manuscript. "Fighter Squadron at Guadalcanal" was published by the Naval Institute Press in 1996.In the introduction, Payne wrote: "This is about Americans engaged in a global struggle for survival. ... It is about a future that we enjoy now but which seemed very uncertain."Said the Palm Springs Air Museum's director, Fred Bell: "He was an extraordinary guy who was very humble, and we can only hope we can live up to his and others' examples and carry on in their footsteps, remembering what they did."

The average life span of a company listed in the S&P 500 index in the 1920s was 67 years. Today it's 15. So note Henry Kressel and Norman Winarsky in "If You Really Want to Change the World: A Guide to Creating, Building and Sustaining Breakthrough Ventures." They say entrepreneurs must find their true north and have a road map…

Barney Barnum was shot at for the first time right after he arrived in South Vietnam in December 1965. As a first lieutenant, he was an artillery observer for E Battery in support of H Company, 2nd, 9th Marines, 3rd Marine Division, at the end of an uneventful operation in a strategic northern province.Then the Viet Cong ambushed the outfit at the village of Ky Phu."We were under intense fire, and I hit the deck," Barnum told IBD from his home in Reston, Va. "I didn't know where the next senior officer was, but the radio operator had been killed instantly and our captain had been mortally wounded. Our medical corpsman tried to get to him and was shot several times. I ran out to the captain and carried him back to a covered position, but he died in my arms."Hero Amid The HeatAccording to his Medal of Honor citation, Barnum retrieved the radio and assumed command of over 100 men, "moving at once into the midst of the heavy fire, rallying and giving encouragement to all units, reorganized them to replace the loss of key personnel and led their attack on enemy positions. ... His sound and swift decisions and his obvious calm served to stabilize the badly decimated units, and his gallant example as he stood repeatedly exposed to point out targets served as inspiration to all."Harvey C. "Barney" Barnum Jr., 75, was born in Cheshire, Conn.A high school overachiever, he entered the Marine Corps' Platoon Leaders program at St. Anselm College in New Hampshire.After graduating with a bachelor's degree in economics in 1962, he was commissioned a Marine Reserve second lieutenant.He did basic training at Quantico, Va., and in 1963 he graduated from the artillery officer course. His first deployment was to Okinawa, Japan, and in 1964 he rose to first lieutenant in the regular Corps.The next year, he was serving as a guard officer at the Marine barracks at Pearl Harbor in Hawaii when he volunteered for combat.After landing in Vietnam, Barnum joined Operation Harvest Moon, slogging 20 miles through the hills and rice paddies of the Phuoc Ha Valley in a monsoon.VC guerrillas were so well hidden that patrols missed them as the Americans passed through Ky Phu, with H Company in the rear.Then the communists attacked."They were smart in taking out the captain and radio operator," Barnum said. "They figured the rest of us would flounder and they'd wipe us out."After helping the corpsman to safety, Barnum directed a counterattack and called in Huey gunships.With his men running out of ammo, he organized the evacuation of the wounded and a 200-yard run for the rest to break out of the trap.Miraculously, Barnum wasn't wounded, though his pack was shot up.The enemy retreated, leaving 104 VC dead, while 2nd Battalion lost 11 and suffered 71 wounded.Barnum would return to the scene with a military historical tour group in 1996.Home And HonoredIn 1966, he was back in Hawaii and promoted to captain.The next year, he went to Washington, D.C., to receive the Medal of Honor, only the fourth Marine to be awarded it during the war (53 would follow). According to the Congressional Medal of Honor Society, 78 recipients from all branches and all wars are alive.Also in 1967, Barnum went to New Orleans to receive the Veterans of Foreign Wars Man of the Year Award from Lt. Gen. Lewis Walt, the assistant chief of staff for manpower. Walt convinced him to be his traveling aide, headquartered in D.C., with the understanding that Barnum could go wherever he wanted after a year.When the time came, Barnum insisted on returning to Vietnam. Medal of Honor recipients weren't supposed to, because they'd already risked their lives far beyond the call of duty, so Walt had to pull some strings.Barnum landed back in the war zone in October 1968. He was promptly appointed commanding officer of the same artillery battery he had served with on his first tour, part of 2nd Battalion, 12th Marines, 3rd Marine Division.Over the next year, he earned a Bronze Star with Combat V and a Gold Star and a Purple Heart.He was wounded during Operation Dewey Canyon, a sweep of northern valleys from January to March 1969, the Marines' last major offensive of the war.Flying High, Then Hit"We built firebases on mountaintops with six guns and engineers so that when the infantry went down into the valley, they would never be out of range," said Barnum. "I had a flag on top of one that Sen. Strom Thurmond had sent me, and my mom had sewn a flag that flew under it with our nickname, Thundering Guns of Death. You're only supposed to fly the U.S. flag in a foreign country at the embassy, but pilots loved seeing it after flying for 10 hours. I was standing in the doorway right under it when (the)enemy mortared and rocketed our position and collapsed the bunker. I took shrapnel, but had it taken out by a corpsman and stayed on."To those who ask how he feels about America winning South Vietnam's freedom with the January 1973 Paris peace treaty, only to see the north's communists overrun Saigon two years later, Barnum has a firm response: "The war was lost by gutless politicians who wouldn't stick with a winning strategy. We never lost a battle, and the failure of the Vietnam insurgency is what ultimately killed the Russian bear. If you were part of ending communism as we know it, you can be proud."On his return to America, he served in a variety of positions, including with U.S. Central Command, helping execute exercises with 26,000 personnel spread over four southwest Asian nations.He was promoted to his final rank of colonel in 1984 and three years later became military secretary to the Marines' commandant.He left the military in 1989 and quickly became principal director of drug enforcement policy for Defense Secretary Dick Cheney.Also that year, a friend set up a blind date for the bachelor with Martha Hill, a widow with two children. They hit it off and married three years later. She works with him on his commitments as a board member of outfits that include Segs4Vets and the Marine Corps Law Enforcement Foundation.In July 2001, Barnum was appointed deputy assistant secretary of the Navy for Reserve affairs.Two months later, the 9/11 terrorists struck, and he grappled with the challenges of preparing Reserve forces for the front lines.For the winter/spring of 2009, he was acting assistant secretary for manpower and Reserve affairs."Our naval and Marine reservists are the citizen soldiers who have a can-do attitude and a wide range of vital skills, from law enforcement to medical, that are essential complements to the full-time military," said Barnum. "They used to be thought of as weekend warriors but are now considered as part of one team. We shouldn't be making manpower budget cuts today so that the military can be an expensive social experiment. We could also save money by having defense companies make what we tell them we need, rather than having them come up with gee-whiz stuff and then try to sell it to us."Terry McKnight, a retired rear admiral, who worked with Barnum at the Pentagon and later wrote the book "Pirate Alley," said: "Over my 30-plus years in the Navy, I had the opportunity to listen and learn from some of the titans of the defense establishment. However, for a student of leadership, the pinnacle of my career was working with Col. Barnum. Day in and day out, his No. 1 concern was the people who worked for him and the thousands of men and women serving in the military."Before I went out to command an amphibious assault ship, he told me, 'Terry, command is very simple: Always take care of your people, and they will take care of you.'"Lots of people in the Pentagon said that, but he lived it every day. After 9/11, he knew our country would change forever and drove his staff to make sure that not only were the Navy and Marine Corps Reserve forces ready to answer the call, but that their families would be taken care of in time of conflict."He is a true hero who has always gone beyond the call of duty."

Edwin Drake completed the first commercial oil…

Douglas MacArthur produced victories in war and peace. He held the rare U.S. Army rank of five-star general — and the only one to receive the Medal of Honor. British Prime Minister Winston Churchill called him the best American commander of World War II — and with good reason. MacArthur (1880-1964) led the battering of Japanese forces in the South…

James Stavridis had no plans to stay in the U.S. Navy, let alone become an admiral. Originally, his goal was to become a Marine officer, like his father, learn leadership skills and switch to a corporate law career.In 1981, as his post-Naval Academy five-year commitment was ending, he applied to top law schools.Then Lt. Cmdr. Mike Mullen, the future chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff and a mentor, called.He recommended that instead of getting stuck with a huge law school bill, Stavridis should accept a scholarship Mullen could arrange to the Fletcher School of Law & Diplomacy at Tufts University in Medford, Mass.This would require only a three-year service commitment.Stavridis agreed — and the military remained his life, all the way to becoming the first admiral in charge of NATO forces.Now he's dean of Fletcher."Everyone should keep an open mind about career goals and seek advice from those who might know your potential better than you do," Stavridis, the author of "The Accidental Admiral," told IBD. "I never dreamed I would spend 37 years in uniform and become a four-star admiral."Florida RiseStavridis, 60, was born in West Palm Beach, Fla., and graduated from the academy at Annapolis, Md., in 1976. By then, he had changed course and become a surface ship warfare officer.One of his first managerial jobs was heading an engineering department, where the sailors worked long hours in hot and dirty conditions far below the top deck."The successful officer will be able to make his people feel privileged," he wrote in his chapter of "Naval Leadership," edited by Thomas Cutler. "He makes them believe in themselves, and the simplest way to do that is to believe in them himself."In 1983, Stavridis earned a master's degree in law and diplomacy from Fletcher and the next year a Ph.D. in international relations."This helped me learn that the world was a diverse place and there were no single silver bullet solutions for its problems, so you have to work with allies and partners, communicating strategically to create answers that would endure," he said.During his postgraduate days he married Laura Hall, who also came from a Navy family and had a degree in international relations. She would go on to do her own advanced studies at Boston University. They have two daughters, Julia and Christina, with the family usually based at Norfolk, Va., while he was often away for months.After rising in the ranks, he landed a big break in 1993, when he took command of the Barry, a new, billion-dollar destroyer.Halfway through his tour, it became the first destroyer to include women, who made up 15% of the 340 sailors. Stavridis recounted his experience in 2007's "Destroyer Captain," amid his sideline of articles that reached 150 and command handbook contributions.Meanwhile, the Barry took Stavridis and his crew 130,000 miles to enforce an arms embargo on Haiti and Serbia, search for Iraqi mines in the Persian Gulf, practice anti-submarine warfare and conduct military exercises — while avoiding frequent hurricanes.Also with Stavridis at the helm, the Barry won the Battenberg Cup as the best-run ship among the 150 vessels in the Atlantic Fleet in 1995.Stavridis has always been a big reader and most mornings devours news, blogs and opinions in English, French and Spanish.A believer in continuous learning and getting different viewpoints, he includes in his "Accidental Admiral" a reading list that runs 20 pages and emphasizes "the importance of the lessons of history."Among his favorites: Edward Luttwak's "The Grand Strategy of the Roman Empire." "The Struggle for Mastery in Europe: 1848-1918" by A.J.P. Taylor. "No Simple Victory: World War II in Europe" by Norman Davies. "Winning the Peace: The Marshall Plan and America's Coming of Age as a Superpower" by Nicolaus Mills.Stavridis writes of the pivotal Battle of Salamis near Athens in 480 B.C. between the small Greek fleet under Themistocles and the vast array of vessels under Persian King Xerxes."Themistocles told his captains the night before to remember to tell the men of the galleys that they rowed first for their parents, then for their children, their city and finally for their freedom," said Stavridis. "Attitude and training were more important than numbers, and they were victorious, enabling the first democracies to thrive and inspire our Founding Fathers."In 1998, Stavridis took command of Destroyer Squadron 21 in the Persian Gulf and received the John Paul Jones Award for inspirational leadership.After running the Navy's first think tank about the 9/11 attacks, he returned to the Persian Gulf in 2002-04 to direct combat operations of the aircraft carrier Enterprise's strike group during the Afghan and Iraq wars.He's reticent about the details, only saying, "There's a thrill to launching a Tomahawk missile."GlobalIn 2006 he became the first admiral of U.S. Southern Command out of Miami, vaulting him on trips to 45 countries with 500 million people. "I worked with Admiral Stavridis as he transformed Southern Command into a model of smart power that uses interagency and private-public relationships in innovative ways that address the multifaceted challenges of the 21st century strategic environment," said retired Army Col. Jorge Silveira, who served as his Commander's Action Group chief. "He put on a full-court press to create a joint command by inviting 15 U.S. government agencies to send representatives to integrate with our headquarters. Among the results was a hospital ship that sailed to countries in the region and saved lives as it supported theater security objectives. His proudest moment was when we helped the Colombia military rescue three American hostages who had been held for over five years by narcoterrorists."Next up for Stavridis, in 2009, was head of U.S. European Command in Stuttgart, Germany, overseeing 100,000 military members.Simultaneously, he commanded 120,000 NATO forces from 51 countries, with headquarters in Mons, Belgium.He was the first admiral in the post after 15 Army and Air Force generals, starting with Dwight Eisenhower in 1950.Stavridis made Silveira his military assistant, and they soon faced crises from piracy off the Horn of Africa to the civil war in Syria.Facing The Enemy"We worked hard to raise the 10,000 allied troops to add to the 30,000 Americans for the Afghanistan surge in 2010, doing everything from trading off desires of certain nations for specific missions to giving speeches, and the effort succeeded," Stavridis said.The next year, he oversaw U.S. and NATO attacks against Libya's dictator, Moammar Gadhafi, ending 222 days later after 24,000 air and missile strikes and 3,000 intercepts at sea.His third big preoccupation was the former Yugoslavia, where NATO had bombed Serb aggressors in Bosnia-Herzegovina in 1995, then in Kosovo in 1999.At the campaign's peak, 60,000 peacekeeping troops were in Kosovo. By the time Stavridis stepped down, 5,000 remained."My biggest disappointment in my four-year tour was our inability to build a better working relationship with the Russians," Stavridis said. "By far my saddest responsibility was having to write 2,400 letters of condolence" for the loved ones of those serving NATO in Afghanistan and elsewhere.In "The Accidental Admiral," Stavridis recommends ways for leaders to be more effective: Prepare for key events. Be your own spokesman. Spend a quarter of your time on personnel matters, from mentoring to meeting new people. Enjoy relaxing weekends. Stay physically fit.His 2012 TED Talk, "A Navy Admiral's Thoughts on Global Security," viewed nearly 700,000 times, digs into the use of smart power, integrating military action with diplomacy, humanitarian aid and other resources to achieve goals.In 2013, he retired from the Navy and became dean at Fletcher.His personal awards include the Defense Distinguished Service Medal, the Navy Distinguished Service Medal, the Defense Superior Service Medal and the Legion of Merit with four stars.

We say that evil is dark. But this metaphor is imprecise. Evil is actually intensely bright, so painfully bright that people look away from it. Many even deny its existence. Why? Because once people acknowledge evil's existence, they know they have to confront it. And most people prefer not to confront evil. That is what led to World War II.…
Tony Zinni is entitled to question conventional military thinking. As a Marine company commander in Vietnam in 1970, he was severely wounded.
In the 1980s, he boosted the Marines' special operations.
During the 1991 Gulf War, he oversaw the Patriot missile defense batteries in Israel.
From 1997 to 2000, Gen. Zinni headed up U.S. Central Command.
He has been in charge of humanitarian and diplomatic missions from Kenya to the Philippines.
Tom Clancy was so impressed that he co-authored the story of Zinni's career, "Battle Ready."

"My generation learned bitter lessons in Vietnam and elsewhere and we swore never to repeat the mistakes, if we ever rose to high command," Zinni, who with Tony Koltz wrote "Before the First Shots Are Fired," told IBD from his home in Williamsburg, Va. "I vowed to speak the truth, even if it hurt my career."
College And War
Anthony Charles Zinni, 71, grew up in Conshohocken in eastern Pennsylvania.

In 1965 he earned a bachelor's degree in economics from Villanova University, near Philadelphia. All the while he was in the Reserve Officers' Training Corps and graduated as a Marine second lieutenant.
With the Vietnam War raging, Zinni went to Camp Lejeune, N.C., for a year, rising to command an infantry training company.
After Army Special Warfare School at Fort Bragg, N.C., where he learned Vietnamese and was promoted to first lieutenant, Zinni headed for Vietnam in March 1967.
He left behind a new bride, Debbie. Their son, Anthony, is now a Marine major.

Zinni became an advisor to Vietnamese marines, calling in U.S. air and artillery firepower. He grew to respect their bravery and skills. He also recognized the dedication of the Viet Cong and North Vietnamese army regulars.

"I came to believe that we could have prevailed if our leaders had bothered to understand the South Vietnamese and had given them a government they were excited to fight for," said Zinni. "We never emphasized winning hearts and minds, while the NVA convinced or coerced them."
He rose to captain in July 1967, and when his 10-month commitment was up, Zinni wanted to extend his tour an additional six.
But he was so sick with a maze of diseases, he had to be shipped to a hospital in Guam. Recovering back in America, he spent two years as a Marine instructor at Quantico, Va.

In August 1970 he returned to South Vietnam as an infantry company commander, based in Da Nang. His battalion boss was Lt. Col. Mick Trainor, whom Zinni calls "one of the smartest officers the Corps ever produced."

In November, Zinni was conducting an operation that ran into strong resistance. Three AK-47 rounds went right through his flak jacket. An emergency operation removed a third of the muscle in his back before he was shipped to Guam for skin grafts from his legs.
By December, he had recovered enough to finish his yearlong tour commanding a supply battalion on Japan's Okinawa Island.
More Death
America's combat role delivered the Paris peace treaty of 1973.
But with U.S. troops gone, South Vietnam fell to the communists two years later.

Thereafter, Zinni pushed for combat command and training positions while sharing his analytical and management skills. "Marines have always tolerated mavericks and encouraged officers to speak out, which has been a big factor in making the Corps an innovator," he explained.
While Maj. Zinni attended the National War College in Washington, D.C., in 1983, Muslim terrorists slaughtered 220 Marines in a barracks bombing in Beirut, Lebanon.
In short order, Lt. Gen. Trainor recruited Zinni to rethink anti-terror strategy. That led to the creation of the Marine Expeditionary Unit,which would go in harrowing spots meant for special forces.
As a colonel in 1987, Zinni took charge of an MEU on Okinawa and conducted security operations in the Philippines.
General On The Go
By 1990, he had his first star and was deputy director of operations at European Command in Stuttgart, Germany, a front-row seat as the Soviet Union came apart.

"But we didn't plan for the end of the Cold War to give stability to a world which had ignored or suppressed other problems for so long, from illegal drugs in Latin America and Islamic extremism to ethnic tensions in the Balkans and disease in Africa," said Zinni. "We naively thought the main result would be a big savings on defense."
After overseeing the Patriot missile defense of Israel during the Gulf War, he headed relief for the Kurds in Iraq and Turkey.

Then came a promotion to major general, plus missions in Somalia later in the 1990s. They helped him see the bigger picture of smart power, the full deployment of assets and skills to reach U.S. goals.
"The military can't go it alone anymore," Zinni said. "We have to have integrated solutions to problems, and we have to stay involved in a closely connected world."
His next big leap came in 1997, when he landed a fourth star and took over U.S. Central Command at MacDill Air Force Base in Tampa, Fla.
His responsibility covered operations in what would soon expand to 25 countries, from East Africa to Central Asia, so he read 50 books to grasp their culture.
The big military operation during this tour was Desert Fox, a series of airstrikes in 1998 to batter Iraq's chemical weapons.
Zinni retired in September 2000 with 22 personal awards in addition to his Purple Heart, including a Defense Distinguished Service Medal and a Bronze Star.
A year later, on 9/11, Muslim terrorists struck again, this time killing 3,000 in New York City and Washington, D.C.
America soon hit back in Afghanistan and Iraq.
Zinni had already prepared a report for U.S. leaders in case of a fight in the Middle East, and he was shocked to learn no one read it.

"Regardless of their original positions on the Iraq and Afghanistan wars, there's a consensus among the retired leaders I know that we relied too much on technology, didn't provide enough troops and didn't do adequate postwar planning," said Zinni. "No one thought we would be putting $2 trillion on a credit card for the first time. Dwight Eisenhower came to the presidency from the strong planning culture of the military, and his presidency is known for its careful decision making, something we haven't seen in recent administrations."
He thinks Eisenhower, who after winning World War II was president from 1953 to 1961, would endorse these ideas to revamp the Pentagon and overall defense:
 Because of conflicts between the advice the Joint Chiefs are supposed to give the president and their loyalties to their services, replace them with former service chiefs or combat commanders.

 Eliminate the unnecessary layer of bureaucracy of the service secretaries and their staffs. Instead, have the services report to the defense secretary through the chairman of the Joint Chiefs, as regional combat commanders do.
 Instead of having so many troops at forward bases, rely more on coalition partners and a rapid-deployment force.

 Fund a more robust staff in nonmilitary agencies to provide humanitarian and political aid after or in lieu of military action. Improve cooperation with countries on economics, energy and education to prevent flare-ups.
"If more Americans would listen to General Zinni, we'd have a better foreign policy and a happier country," said Thomas Ricks, author of "The Generals."

After retiring, Zinni served on corporate boards and in 2009 was CEO of BAE Systems' North American unit. He's now on the board of Michael Baker International, a Pittsburgh engineering and consulting firm. He also serves on the boards of many not-for-profits, including Colonial Williamsburg.
Meanwhile, he teaches at the Joint Forces Staff College in Norfolk, Va., and in the executive program at Villanova University.
He's also a student, working on a master's degree in negotiation from Creighton University. If he doesn't ace that, you have a scoop; he's been on many diplomatic missions, from Israel to Indonesia.
"I practiced negotiation before, but now I want to understand the theory," he explained.
This would be his third master's. The others are in international relations from Salve Regina University in Rhode Island and in management from Central Michigan University.

"I've always had an unquenchable thirst for knowledge," he said.Tony Zinni is entitled to question conventional military thinking. Army Col. James Van Fleet led his men on D-Day, but they landed at the wrong place on Utah Beach. "As commander of the 8th Infantry Regiment, 4th Division, he had learned to seize opportunities where he could, so he made the decision to move forward, leading from the front," Michael Haskew, author of "West Point 1915: Eisenhower, Bradley and the Class the Stars Fell On," told IBD. "He had overcome obstacles by sheer perseverance throughout his career that would have thwarted individuals of lesser constitution, taking the action he could wherever he was."Belatedly recognized for his leadership, he ended World War II as a major general.The next year, 1946, President Truman sent him to Greece to help the government defeat communist insurgents.Then in 1951, as a lieutenant general, he commanded Allied troops that routed North Korean and Chinese communists and was awarded the rank of full general."General Van Fleet is the greatest general we have ever had," said Truman. "I sent him to Greece and he won the war. I sent him to Korea and he won the war."Van Fleet (1892-1992) was born in Fort Lee, N.J., soon before his family moved to Bartow, Fla., when he was still an infant.To The PointHe entered the U.S. Military Academy at West Point in 1911, but was a slow reader who didn't have good study habits. He wrote to his father, saying he should probably drop out, but was encouraged to persevere. He told himself, "I can take it," a lesson he never forgot.He graduated in 1915 as a second lieutenant, among 36% of his class of 164 who were destined to become generals. Included were Dwight Eisenhower and Omar Bradley, who would receive five stars, and three would get four, one of them the late-bloomer Van Fleet.During leave on Christmas Day, Van Fleet married Helen Moore in Carnegie, Pa., and they would have two daughters and a son.After moving around the country as an instructor in the run-up to WWI, he joined the 16th Machine Gun Battalion of the 6th Division as it set sail for France in July 1918.First Lt. Van Fleet was soon in the trenches, and in November — the month the war ended — was wounded by a bomb.He returned home in June 1919.Van Fleet rose to major the next year and taught military leadership at Kansas State. Then he did the same at the University of Florida while coaching the football team to winning seasons in 1923 and 1924.By 1927 he was at Fort Benning, Ga., where Lt. Col. George Marshall was innovating infantry tactics.Van Fleet rose to lieutenant colonel in 1936 while training reserves in San Diego. Three years later the Nazis invaded Poland, so he was called back to Fort Benning to command 1st Battalion, 29th Infantry Regiment, which would demonstrate tactics to other units.In June 1941, Van Fleet assumed the rank of colonel and took over the 8th Infantry Regiment."Many of his classmates had been rapidly promoted, and it was alleged that the reason for his career stagnation was that Marshall, who was named Army chief of staff in 1939, had confused him with an alcoholic officer with a similar name," said Steve Taaffe, author of "Marshall and His Generals." "Instead of becoming bitter and despondent, though, Van Fleet focused on the task at hand, even if it was beneath his talents. Generals Eisenhower, Bradley and Joe Lawton Collins were said to have eventually cleared up the matter with Marshall."On June 6, 1944, at 4 a.m., the 8th Regiment was headed for the wrong landing point in the chaos of the invasion of Normandy, France, with Van Fleet initially behind in a command ship."After more than three years of training and planning, it was the first to make an amphibious landing on Utah Beach," wrote Paul Braim in "The Will to Win: The Life of General James A. Van Fleet." "The lessons learned would save lives, and then-Capt. George Mabry, remembering his moment of trial after retirement as a major general with a Medal of Honor, said Van Fleet was 'the best leader I have ever encountered, and I've encountered a lot of them.'"Van Fleet joined his men on the beach and led them deeper into Normandy. His jeep roamed the front line over the next four days, and he was slightly wounded.Bradley was astounded at what he saw and gave Van Fleet his first of three Distinguished Service Crosses, the military's second highest award, on the spot.The regiment continued to lead the division in fierce fighting over the next two weeks that ended with the capture of Cherbourg."He worked hard to gain intimate knowledge of his unit's personnel and operation, studying and analyzing not only the manpower, firepower and terrain under his control, but the same features for the enemy," said Keith Huxen, senior research director at the National WW2 Museum in New Orleans. "He knew that he would be successful if he mastered these details."A StarIn August, Van Fleet became a brigadier general, and in October took over the 90th Division, which had lagged at Normandy.He promptly made the outfit live up to its nickname, the Tough Ombres. Recalled one of its GIs, "He acted as if he expected success, and he got it."In November, the same month Van Fleet was made major general, the retrained 90th had its first big test in an assault across the Moselle River toward Germany.His men took heavy casualties the first three days, then pushed the enemy back. "Swiftness, mobility, unrelenting attack — these were Van Fleet's principles, in football as in war," wrote Braim. "He would regard the Moselle campaign as his finest hour."The 90th pursued the retreating Germans to the Siegfried Line near the Saar River, where the defensive barrier of the border of Germany was most highly developed.The Americans made a surprise attack in December and, despite strong resistance, pushed inland, capturing many prisoners.Just then, the 90th rushed north to counter the German offensive that was the Battle of the Bulge.In March 1945, Bradley urgently ordered Van Fleet to take over III Corps, which had just crossed the Rhine River at Remagen, Germany, the first major unit to do so.By mid-April, Van Fleet had directed III Corps' encirclement of the industrial heartland of the Ruhr Valley and captured over 100,000 prisoners. The Nazi high command surrendered on May 7.All Over The MapVan Fleet arrived home in June and took over the 2nd Service Command in New York City. The unit involved the Army Reserve.In February 1948, Truman promoted him to lieutenant general and put him in charge of helping the Greek government defeat the insurgency backed by the Soviet Union. Starting with a poorly armed and badly led force, Van Fleet oversaw $300 million in aid, equipment and training, and by 1950 his Greeks had triumphed.Van Fleet returned to Washington and helped the Army prepare a response to the North Korean invasion of the South in June 1950.In September, Gen. Douglas MacArthur's U.S. and U.N. troops pushed back the communists and captured the North's capital.But in November, the Chinese army poured over the border, and the Allies were forced back into South Korea. Then came a political thunderstorm, with MacArthur criticizing the American strategy in public in March 1951 and Truman replacing him with Gen. Matthew Ridgway, commander of the 8th Army, the main U.S. force.Van Fleet was rushed to take over the 8th in April, and a week later a communist force of 700,000 struck. He directed a tactical withdrawal and blunted the offensive, inflicting 70,000 casualties.The 8th then pushed the communists north of the border, inflicting an additional 200,000 casualties.In July 1951, Van Fleet received his fourth star. Peace talks started the same month, but fighting continued.The next April, his son, a B-26 bomber pilot, was shot down over North Korea and died.The general left for home in early 1953 and retired. The armistice was signed that July.Van Fleet lived to 100 and died at his ranch near Polk City, Fla.

George Washington had only a few decisive battlefield victories. But he soared as a strategist. "Strategic military planning starts with a clear vision of desired goals, to achieve the reasons for which a nation goes to war," Dave Palmer, author of "George Washington's Military Genius," told IBD. "Strategists must consider key factors influencing operations, such as tactics, weapons, geography and the quality of their forces. But the foremost factor is a full consideration of the enemy — his aims, strengths, weaknesses and capabilities. Perhaps the best example of strategic military leadership in American history is Washington."Palmer, a retired Army three-star general and former West Point superintendent, says few histories of the American Revolution recognize its four phases and how Washington reacted correctly to each: From April 1775 to mid-1776, Americans had superior forces, and he was bold. Mid-1776 through 1777, the British army was larger and better, and he was cautious. 1778-81, bolstered by French military and naval forces, he sought decisive battle. 1782-83, with war weariness sweeping the land, he generated the will to persevere.Against daunting odds, he led Americans to independence.Virginia RiseWashington (1732-99) was born to wealthy tobacco planters near present-day Colonial Beach, Va., but his father died when he was 11.Receiving the equivalent of an elementary school education, he was a big reader the rest of his life.At 17, he was appointed to a well-paid position as county surveyor that let him buy 1,500 acres over the next two years.In 1752, Washington rose to major in the Virginia militia. As relations between France and Britain heated up, the governor sent him on a dangerous mission to the Ohio Valley to tell French troops to leave, but they refused.Two years later, Washington led Colonial troops at the start of the French and Indian War.By 1755, Lt. Col. Washington was an aide to British Gen. Edward Braddock during a 1,300-man expedition to the Ohio.They were ambushed and 465 were killed, including Braddock. Washington displayed bravery leading the retreat, as two horses were shot from under him and musket balls pierced his clothing. The governor made him a colonel and chief of the Virginia Regiment."Unique among the founders of the U.S., Washington's primary education came from living life in its rawest form, deep in the woods, often with death a nearby companion," wrote Alonzo McDonald in "Character Counts," edited by Os Guinness. "The endless physical hardships he endured tested him in every way, and he survived by indomitable willpower, hardened to ridicule, failure and paucity of resources."Washington retired to Virginia's Mount Vernon in 1758 at the end of the war and married a widow, Martha Custis, in 1759. Their land made them wealthy, though they were cash poor, and Washington diversified their crops and investments to pay debts.The expense of the war caused London's Parliament to tax the Colonies, starting with the Stamp Act in 1765. Protests led to the shots heard around the world at Lexington and Concord in April 1775.The next month, Washington was a delegate to the Continental Congress in Philadelphia and accepted command of the Continental Army.He forced the British out of Boston in March 1776. But in August, 20,000 redcoats landed on Long Island, N.Y., and crushed the 9,000 Colonials.The Americans suffered more defeats until Washington crossed the Delaware River from New Jersey to Pennsylvania in early December, taking the only boats with them so the British couldn't maneuver. With the weather worsening, the Brits set up winter quarters while many of their Hessian mercenaries were in Trenton."It was the darkest hour of the Revolution, with Washington losing 90% of the Army to battle, disease, desertion and enlistments that were up at the end of the month," said Gregory Aldrete, author of the Great Courses' audiovisual program "The Decisive Battles of World History." "He knew he had to do something dramatic and planned an attack before dawn the day after Christmas at Trenton, knowing that the 1,500 Hessians would be hung over."Washington's 2,400 men embarked as the darkness, sleet, snow and river ice made the crossing dire. Still, they surprised the enemy, killing or wounding 116 and capturing 950; the rest fled.On Jan. 2, 1777, after convincing some of his men to re-enlist and recruiting from the countryside, he returned with 1,400 against 1,000 British regulars at Princeton, inflicting 100 casualties and taking 200 prisoners. "By a series of daring maneuvers, Washington's twin victories restored the confidence of the Army and saved the Revolution," said Aldrete.Here Came The FrenchIn October 1777 came a significant American victory, with Gen. Horatio Gates beating the redcoats at Saratoga, N.Y.The victory convinced France to become America's ally.Then came the winter at Valley Forge, Pa., where 2,500 of Washington's men died from cold, disease and malnutrition.Washington's winter camp of 1778-79 was again at Valley Forge, where an effort by some officers to replace him failed. "Washington's influence over his officers would have been limited had his integrity been an abstract virtue," wrote Caroline Cox in "The Art of Command," edited by Harry Laver and Jeffrey Matthews.The winter of 1779-80 was brutal, with the American soldiers ready to revolt. "With powers bordering on the mystical at times, Washington was able to calm the mutineers, appealing to them not to discard the 'time, blood and treasure' they had invested in the war," wrote Harlow Unger in "'Mr. President': George Washington and the Making of the Nation's Highest Office."On New Year's Day, 1781, 1,500 Pennsylvania veterans near the end of their enlistments marched toward Congress in Philadelphia."Washington desperately needed their manpower and wrote to the notoriously hot-headed Brig. Gen. Anthony Wayne to avoid a reaction that could drive them into the arms of the British," said Stephen Brumwell, author of "George Washington: Gentleman Warrior." "He told him to find out their grievances and address them. His counsel to talk, not intimidate, defused the crisis, as most of the mutineers re-enlisted."The End Was NighIn the spring of 1781, British Gen. Charles Cornwallis headed for Yorktown on the Virginia coast to get more men and supplies from the British navy.In September that year, Washington marched south with 9,000 Americans and 7,800 French to corner the 8,000 redcoats.With French ships driving off the royal navy, Washington oversaw an artillery bombardment of the British field fort. It led to Cornwallis surrendering and the British sailing home in mid-October.It was the last major battle, but a peace treaty was two years off. The delay meant that Washington had to keep his Army in the field."He knew he commanded the love and respect of his troops, serving without pay and remaining with them in camp through the most severe winters," said Unger. "Most officers in the world's armies routinely left their men in winter quarters and returned to the comforts of their homes or rented quarters."Washington retired to Mount Vernon after war's end. But the Articles of Confederation, which set up a weak government, made paying the veterans impossible.After the ratification of the U.S. Constitution brought a more powerful central government, Washington served as president from 1789 to 1797, sometimes threatening military action to quash anti-tax rebellions."Fearing anarchy, disunion and an end to American freedom if he failed to act decisively, he transformed the presidency from being a relatively impotent figurehead position to one with immense powers," said Unger.Two years after stepping down, Washington died at 67."The outcome of the Revolution was the result of many factors, but at the head of the list must stand the strategic acumen of the American commander in chief," said Palmer. "He won for a variety of reasons, not the least of which was he out-generaled all his opponents."

Gouverneur Morris was among the most important leaders in America's early history. Undeterred by a physical handicap or being from family loyal to Britain, he played a crucial role:  Writing New York state's constitution.  Sending sharpshooters to help win the first American victory at Saratoga, N.Y., in 1777.  Spearheading legislation to supply the Continental Army.  Authoring…

Daniel Morgan turned the tide of the American Revolution. The frontiersman equipped his Virginians with the Kentucky rifle, whose barrel had thin walls to make it light and grooves inside to make it more accurate at a longer range than a British musket.
